column4: description

180 Degrees Consulting is the world's largest student-run consultancy, dedicated to helping nonprofits and social enterprises improve their services, expand their reach, and ultimately maximize their impact. We are a team of motivated, enterprising students from diverse academic backgrounds, united by our passion to make a difference. 180 DC associates not only gain practical experience and first-hand exposure to Boston's social enterprises but also receive professional training from major consulting firms. By connecting passionate individuals and fully equipping them to find effective and innovative solutions to real-world challenges, we develop a community of leaders and social-thinkers. For more information, sign up for our mailing list here or navigate to our website or Instagram: @180dcboston.

Our purpose is to engage in meaningful volunteer work, fundraising opportunities, and awareness activities to support those affected by cancer. We do this in conjunction with the Sunrise Association and the Lymphoma and Leukemia Society, who both share a common goal of improving the quality of life of those affected by cancer and their families. Often isolated from the normal activities of daily life, those with cancer and their families rarely have a chance to experience beyond the closed worlds of home, the hospital and doctor's offices. We aim to open more doors for these individuals, making it possible for them to enjoy exciting daily activities, grow meaningful friendships and participate in various opportunities.

The Sahelian Student Association (SSA) at Boston University is dedicated to uniting Sahelian students and raising awareness about issues facing the Sahel region in Africa. Through events like Sudan Night, where we spotlight the ongoing conflict in Sudan, we strive to educate our community about social conflicts within the region. Our commitment to cultural celebration is evident in our diverse array of events, from a Cultural Hot-Takes event to a Waist-bead Making Night. These activities provide opportunities for members to learn about the rich traditions, languages, and customs of the Sahel region. SSA also acts as a bridge, fostering connections and friendships that transcend borders. We create a welcoming environment for Sahelian students and non-Sahelian students alike, by promoting a sense of belonging and support. Additionally, we partner with local nonprofits for community outreach, contributing to the wider African community in the Boston area.

column1: Above the Haze: a Chi Alpha Campus Ministry
column4: ATH is a student organization devoted to exploring and responding to the claims and teachings of Jesus Christ. We are open to all students, and we hope to create an open environment where those outside the church can bring their questions and explore the life of Jesus. We believe that Jesus is central to our development and that the university experience is incomplete and pale without actively involving him in our lives. The Christian life can be summed up in four areas of growth: our heart, mind, will, and strength.

Bridging the gap between the academic and professional worlds, the BU Accounting Association sponsors events that bring the industry to the classroom. Highlights include student internship panels, company information sessions, mock interviews, resume workshops, CPA Becker panels, office tours, and more.

Boston University's professional quality, student-driven advertising agency. We blend strategic insights, creative risks, and fresh perspectives to craft bold campaigns for our broad range of clients. Our agency fosters career development through hands-on learning and mentorship, preparing students to excel in advertising and beyond. Open to all, regardless of experience or major, we create real work with real results. Interested in joining? Check us out on our socials or email us today!

The Adopted and Multicultural Student Alliance (AMSA) is a student-led community for adoptees, members of adoptive families, and anyone interested in learning about adoptive experiences and the multicultural identity that often accompanies. This community aims to connect members and provide opportunities for personal development and growth through discussions, social and cultural events, and giving back to the community. Originally founded as the International Adoptee Club in 2021, we have expanded our mission to reflect the diverse community that falls under the large umbrella of adoption, including domestic, international, interracial, foster care, or open adoption to name a few. Our mission is to create a welcoming community where members can connect, share experiences, and explore the adoptive identity. Through open discussions, social and cultural events, and community engagement, we aim to: Build community and connections Foster pride and comfort in the adoptive and multicultural identity Challenge stigmas surrounding adoption Provide guidance and give back to the adoptive community

Boston University's African Students Organization strives to create an inclusive, celebratory, and educational space to uplift African countries, cultures, and people. We serve as a cultural, social, political, and humanitarian support network for African students at BU.

Afrithms proudly represents Boston University as its premier African dance troupe, celebrating a decade of captivating performances that fuse the rich rhythms and movements of diverse African cultures. Founded on a passion for cultural expression, Afrithms has not only entertained audiences but also competed and showcased their talent at numerous prestigious venues and events throughout the years. Their energetic performances have become a staple in the Greater Boston Area, leaving a lasting impression wherever they appear. At the heart of Afrithms' success is their commitment to self-expression and creativity. The majority of their choreography is original, crafted to reflect the latest trends in African dance and music. This dedication to innovation ensures that each performance is both authentic and dynamic, captivating audiences with its blend of tradition and contemporary flair. Beyond their performances, Afrithms serves as a cultural hub on campus, fostering a community where students from diverse backgrounds come together to explore and celebrate African and Caribbean heritage through dance. Their rehearsals and workshops not only hone dance skills but also promote cultural understanding and appreciation among participants.

BUAIS is an interdisciplinary academic club that brings together students with a passion for exploring the vast realm of artificial intelligence (AI). The club is open to all Boston University students, regardless of their major or academic year. We aim to foster an inclusive, innovative, and intellectually stimulating environment that encourages members to engage in discussions, develop projects, and participate in events related to AI. The club's primary objective is to promote the understanding of AI, its potential applications across a range of disciplines, and its ethical, societal, and economic implications. BUAIS provides opportunities for students to gain hands-on experience with AI and machine learning technologies (with focus on Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing), foster connections with industry professionals and AI researchers, and actively contribute to a rapidly evolving field. Motivation for the club: The advent of AI has revolutionized our world, impacting a wide range of fields including healthcare, finance, transportation, entertainment, and many more. As AI continues to advance, so too does the demand for skilled professionals in this field. BUAIS aims to fill the gap between classroom learning and practical, real-world application of AI, equipping students with the necessary skills and knowledge to thrive in this emerging field. In addition, BUAIS will serve as a platform for students to discuss and debate the ethical, societal, and economic implications of AI, encouraging members to consider these important issues from diverse perspectives. We believe that this multifaceted understanding of AI is crucial in shaping future AI policies, systems, and applications.

Serving as the official Boston University Arts & Literary Club, the student organization publication aims to publish the creativity of students pursuing a degree at Boston University by intertwining art and literature into one space. Through a combination of visual and written pieces, ALC will represent the vibrant artistry bubbling throughout the BU community. The student organization encourages submissions ranging from poems and short stories to sketches and photographs. ALC hopes to act as a medium to reveal the collective yet unique creative talents of students at Boston University, and encourages submissions from any and all Boston University students. Read the magazine on our website!

The Alexander Hamilton Society (AHS) is a non-partisan, not-for-profit, national organization that seeks to identify, educate, and launch young men and women into foreign policy and national security careers imbued with the Hamiltonian perspective of strong and principled American leadership in global affairs. Grounded in a nationwide foundation of student-driven campus chapters, our network works to revitalize American foreign policy. Through the vehicle of informed debate, our campus programming is critical to the intellectual and professional development of a new generation of American leaders. We act as a bridge between promising student leaders to internships, graduate programs, and professional opportunities in the worlds of academia, business, finance, policymaking, politics, and journalism. While our focus is on the long term, our alumni have already achieved significant influence in their professional pursuits, rebuilding the ranks of talented citizens looking to serve their country over the course of their lives and careers.

Alianza Latina is Boston University's largest Latinx student organization and the Latine Student Union. We are dedicated to providing BU students with programming that fosters community and encourages students to learn more about Latinx culture and identity, regardless of their own race or ethnicity. We implement weekly cultural, social, and professional meetings as well as community service events both on and off campus.

The Allegrettos are a student-run, all-gender a cappella group at Boston University. Founded in 1994, the group performs throughout the northeast region, records music, and competes in competitions such as the ICCAs. In 2016, The Allegrettos performed for President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama at the White House! The Allegrettos bring a unique blend of alternative-pop, R&B, and gospel influence to their repertoire. Passionate about recording and sharing their artistry, the group has released a growing catalog of EPs, albums, and singles—available on all major streaming platforms. Frequent competitors in the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella (ICCA), The Allegrettos have a long list of awards, most recently earning 2nd Place in the 2024 ICCA Northeast Quarterfinals and advancing to the Semifinals, winning outstanding soloist and choreography.

The Allocations Board is an organization on BU's campus tasked with distributing a portion of the Community Student Fee (CSF) to on- and off-campus events held by undergraduate student organizations. The AB is composed entirely of undergraduates from across BU's schools, residence halls, and student groups. Though each member attends every meeting and works through breaks, members receive no compensation other than the joy of supporting and encouraging great events. We hope this site serves both as a resource to groups requesting funding and for students curious about how their CSF is distributed, and how they can become involved in the process. Please contact us, either through this site or at allocate@bu.edu with any questions or concerns.

column1: Association of Latino Professionals for America
column4: ALPFA is a national non-profit organization that has become the largest Latino Association for business professionals and students with more than 92,000 members nationwide, this includes 43 professional and over 150 student chapters. ALPFA connects students with hundreds of its Fortune 1000 partners, providing them access to 50,000 paid summer internships. In addition, ALPFA has hosts events at a local, regional, and national level to develop students from college to career-ready professionals through mentorship, leadership training and development, job placement and philanthropy. Please email us at alpfa@bu.edu or find us on social media @alpfabu for more information!

Alpha Chi Sigma (AXS/ΑΧΣ) is a national co-educational, professional chemistry fraternity dedicated to providing opportunities for study and leadership, as well as forming friendships and connections among students interested in chemistry and related fields. Founded on December 11, 1902, at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, AXS unites collegiate and professional members from a vast range of majors, careers, and professions under the three objects of the fraternity: To bind its members with a tie of true and lasting friendship. To strive for the advancement of chemistry both as a science and as a profession. To aid its members by every honorable means in the attainment of their ambitions as chemists throughout their mortal lives. Through membership, community service, professional development, and social events, AXS aims to serve as the gateway that brings together students from different backgrounds, interests, and mindsets. If you are interested, please check out our website, Instagram, and Facebook in the contact section below, and keep an eye out for our info sessions at the beginning of each semester. Don't hesitate to ask us questions at axs@bu.edu!

Alpha Epsilon Delta, the only national pre-health honor society, was founded in 1926 at the University of Alabama and is currently one of the 57 members of the Association of College Honor Societies. The primary objectives of AED include promoting the pursuit of scholarly excellence, establishing a network among pre-health students and health educators and professionals, and creating opportunities for personal, intellectual, and professional development. AED serves to prepare students for a life of service. The Boston University Massachusettes Gamma chapter of AED was established in 1979. Members of BU's chapter of AED have organized and participated in social events, informational series, and volunteer projects each school year. These activities have been organized in order to foster a sense of community for the students in AED, to promote pre-health careers, and to benefit the greater Boston community.

Alpha Epsilon Phi is a national sorority, founded in 1909 by seven women, dedicated to helping women become the best they can be. We prize individuality, encouraging each member to discover and develop the talents and abilities that make her unique.But just as we value individuality, we also prize togetherness, fostering friendships and a sense of belonging that last a lifetime. When you're an AEΦ, you'll find there's always a sister to laugh when you laugh, to listen when you talk, to lend a hand and be there for you. Mission Statement:The mission of Alpha Epsilon Phi Sorority is to inspire and support exemplary women dedicated to friendship and a lifelong commitment to Alpha Epsilon Phi while building on the vision of our founders.

Epsilon Chapter became Massachusetts' first undergraduate chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated when it was chartered on May 3, 1924 at Boston University. Since 1924, Epsilon immediately began its legacy of outstanding service and leadership through its innovative programs geared towards solving socio-economic issues within the community. With enthusiasm, strength and pride, the chapter continued to push Alpha Kappa Alpha into the public eye as a premier service organization dedicated to serving all of Mankind. As the Greater Boston City Chapter, the Everloving, Everlasting Epsilon Chapter is dedicated to serving its constituents. It is composed of Babson College, Bentley College, Boston College, Boston University, Brandeis University, Emerson College, Emmanuel College, Pine Manor College, Simmons College, Suffolk University and Tufts University.

alpha Kappa Delta Phi was established at the University of California, Berkeley in the fall of 1989. Four headstrong visionaries: Susan Kim, Fannie Pon, Jill Yoshimura and Reina Yuan, initiated the concept of having an organization that would provide them as well as other young college women the opportunity to experience sisterhood, and to promote what they felt was integral to the development of successful women. After proposing their ideas to women at the Berkeley campus, they along with ten and strong and willful fellow women became the founding sisters of alpha Kappa Delta Phi. Together as the charter class, they dedicated themselves to establishing a strong and lasting organization that would foster not only sisterhood, but scholarship, service, leadership and Asian American awareness as well. The founding sisters: Betty Chu, Karin Co, Susan Kim, Nancy Lee, Sherri Leung, Annie Loo, Belinda Ma, Anita Ng, Serene Ngin, Fannie Pon, Josie Sun, Daisy Wu, Jill Yoshimura and Reina Yuan, came together to share one another's goals for a promising union. These ideals were to later set the foundation and purpose for alpha Kappa Delta Phi. The love and generosity that each member had for the organization was instrumental to the growth of alpha Kappa Delta Phi's reputation as a sorority, as well as to the forging of unbreakable friendships. In its first step towards achieving widespread acknowledgement, alpha Kappa Delta Phi was recognized by the College Panhellenic Association of Berkeley, California on February 7, 1990, which date is celebrated annually as National Founders' Day. The sisterhood has since then spread to prominent university campuses around the nation. To meet the needs of the growing sisterhood, the National Board of alpha Kappa Delta Phi was established in May of 1993 at the National Convention in Santa Barbara, California. It is the sincere wish of the founding sisters that alpha Kappa Delta Phi continue to promote the ideals on which the organization was founded and to provide each woman with the resources, unique sisterly support and understanding to achieve her goals in life. Our mission is to provide sisterhood among women, scholarship, leadership and Asian-awareness in the University and community. Further, also to provide a support group for those in their times of need and to encourage the making of successful women. To accomplish our mission, we will: Create a climate that encourages teamwork, creativity and innovation, and above all, Give our unmoving and absolute support and encouragement to those we hold dear to our hearts.

Alpha Kappa Psi is recognized as the premier developer of principled business leaders. As a professional business fraternity, Alpha Kappa Psi offers an inclusive community with expansive opportunities for networking, mentorship, and professional development.

Founded in 1872 by ten forward thinking women at Syracuse University, Alpha Phi is now one of the oldest and largest women's fraternities in North America. The Eta Chapter of Alpha Phi was founded in 1883 and recently celebrated its 125th anniversary at Boston University. Alpha Phi is one of the largest sororities on Boston University's campus. Although sororities do not have houses at BU, many sisters choose to live together on and off campus. Alpha Phi is visible on campus through attendance at sporting, philanthropy and greek events in addition to hosting multiple philanthropy events. Our three largest annual events are Ivy Man, Alpha Phifa, and The Red Dress Brunch, benefit the Alpha Phi Foundation and the American Heart Association. Alpha Phis are not only philanthropic, but scholarly too! Alpha Phi hosts study hours every week and have an alumni mentorship program which connects current members with alumna.
The 17th house of Alpha Phi Alpha, Fraternity, Inc. is the first black Greek lettered organization in Boston, Massachusetts encompassing multiple schools.

LEADERSHIP. FRIENDSHIP. SERVICE. Alpha Phi Omega (APO) is the largest gender-inclusive community service organization in the United States. Our pillars of Leadership, Friendship, and Service guide us as we give back to our campus, community, and country all while making lifelong friendships and gaining essential leadership and professional skills. At BU, the Zeta Upsilon chapter of more than 100 active members unites through our shared passion for ethical volunteerism, commitment to active citizenship, and interest in Boston's unique social justice issues. We offer a variety of service opportunities to address topics ranging from hunger and homelessness to community initiatives and public education. With partners such as the American Red Cross Food Pantry, Community Servings, Women's Lunch Place, East End House, and the Boston Bruins Foundation, there's always a way to make a responsible and effective difference locally! You can learn more about us at https://www.apo-zu.org and follow our Instagram @apozu to see what we're up to! Pledging is open at the beginning of each semester. Please email pledgemaster.buapo@gmail.com or president.buapo@gmail.com for more information.

Welcome to the Rho chapter of Alpha Delta Pi! We have a strong sisterhood and a history of excellence. We are a diverse group of women who make a difference in each other's lives, in the community, and on campus. Alpha Delta Pi was founded in 1851, the first ever secret society for women. Rho chapter of Alpha Delta Pi came to Boston University in 1911 and has a long tradition of sisterhood, with our sisters coming from a variety of backgrounds. With a strong commitment to academic excellence, Alpha Delta Pi has held one of the top GPA averages among all sororities for many semesters. Sisters have a variety of academic interests, ensuring there is always a sister who can help you succeed. Alpha Delta Pi also holds two large philanthropy events each year -- Friday Night Lights, a flag-football tournament in the Fall, and a unique event each Spring. Each year, we raise thousands of dollars for our national philanthropy, Ronald McDonald House Charities. We are lucky enough to be able to directly serve the Ronald McDonald House located in Boston Harbor, which is a facility specifically for families whose children are receiving treatment in Boston. Our commitment to our sorority and to each other is strong. Please explore our website and social media platforms to learn more about Alpha Delta Pi!

Alzheimer's is a prominent disease in the United States, affecting over 5 million Americans, with no cure. As a member of this organization, you will have the opportunity to interact with residents at a local memory care facility, to reflect on these experiences in journals and group meetings, and to discuss the latest developments in Alzheimer's research.

The Boston University branch of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics is a professional society dedicated to supporting BU engineers in finding lifelong resources and opportunities in the field. What We Do: 1. Networking Opportunities 2. Conferences & Events 3. Professional Development 4. Scholarships 5. Technical Design Competitions and more Please visit our website for a more in depth description

column1: American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
column4: The American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology is a national organization that works to construct a network of undergraduate students and faculty for the advancement of research, education, and science outreach. Our student chapter provides networking and career development opportunities at regional and national conferences and access to research and science outreach through grant and award funding to all of our members. If you want to learn more about what we do, check out our website and social media linked down below. For those who want to join, simply email us at asbmbu@bu.edu or wait for our info sessions at the beginning of each semester. Chemistry, BMB, Biology CMG, and related majors are all welcome, and feel free to contact us if you have any questions!

ASME is a not-for-profit membership organization that enables collaboration, knowledge sharing, career enrichment, and skills development across all engineering disciplines, toward a goal of helping the global engineering community develop solutions to benefit lives and livelihoods. Founded in 1880 by a small group of leading industrialists, ASME has grown through the decades to include more than 130,000 members in 158 countries. Thirty-thousand of these members are students. From college students and early-career engineers to project managers, corporate executives, researchers and academic leaders, ASME's members are as diverse as the engineering community itself. ASME serves this wide-ranging technical community through quality programs in continuing education, training and professional development, codes and standards, research, conferences and publications, government relations and other forms of outreach. The Boston University chapter of ASME hosts information sessions and networking events for career advice and insight into academia and graduate school. We also host the yearly FE Exam preparation course enabling students interested in taking the FE exam to have the problems explained by ME faculty. To contact ASME@BU: asme@bu.edu

column1: American Studies Program Graduate Student Association (Graduate)
column4: The American and New England Studies Graduate Student Association was founded in the spring of 2012 to meet a growing desire for greater community networking and support, to foster collegiality and creative thinking, and to represent student interests in an official manner to the university as well as to the larger community of American Studies graduate programs and scholars both here and abroad.The Association hosts student colloquia (The Americanist Forum), facilitates networking amongst groups and individuals with similar scholarly interests and goals, hosts professional development opportunities, and works to build interdisciplinary, scholarly community at Boston University.

The Anime Club is a social group in which both anime enthusiasts and dabblers in the Boston University community can come watch, discuss, and learn more about anime. Our main offering is providing weekly anime programming open to the BU community. We gather in CAS B12 at 6:30PM on most Fridays. We also offer on-campus community events and off-campus group excursions throughout the year. We also have a large library of Blu-rays, light novels, and manga which members can rent throughout the semester. Join our Discord and say hi: https://discord.gg/8ysYsdFV

We are Anthropology in the Works, a student collective of anthropologists, educators, and activists in training. We envision a world where Anthropology is accessible and understandable beyond academia and theory. We strive to teach how it can be embodied and integrated into personal life and public engagement. We are dedicated to learning more about the traditions and customs of different cultures by hosting and participating in events around campus and the Boston area. We also offer students the opportunity to meet with and get to know the dedicated BU Anthropology Department. Through excursions, discussions, presentations, and celebrations we hope that any student interested in Anthropology can experience firsthand what it means to be an Anthropologist.

A student-run organization that focuses on bringing together students of Portuguese heritage and speakers of Portuguese. We hope to connect students from a myriad of diverse cultural backgrounds to practice, learn, and enrich individual knowledge of Portuguese culture and language.

BUArabs intends to create a community for Arabs at Boston University. We hope to share our passions with Arab students and Non-Arab students interested in our culture. Proud of our heritage, we seek to promote solidarity and identity for all club members. Our social, cultural, and celebratory events are meant to embrace our diverse community. Together, we will create a platform for members to express their ideas and grow academically, socially, and professionally. In doing so, we hope students feel a sense of being back home.

Our mission is to learn about, understand, and promote awareness of Archaeology and related fields such as Anthropology, Cultural Hertiage, and Art History all while having an awesome time! We offer an environment in which students can explore and discuss issues relating to Archaeology while participating in a wide variety of activities including workshops, field trips, and lectures. Our club could be your greatest resource for receiving tips on how to become a more competitive archaeologist, getting information on joining a field school, or interacting with celebrated professionals from Boston University and abroad. If you are an Archaeology or Anthropology major, or even if you just have an interest in the exciting field of archaeology, we invite you to explore our website, come to our meetings and activities, or email us to see what we're all about.

column1: Arch?, Boston University's Student-Led Journal of Philosophy
column4: Arché, Boston University's Student-Led Journal of Philosophy, is edited and published by motivated, inquisitive undergraduate students from diverse academic backgrounds in the College of Arts & Sciences in coordination with the Department of Philosophy. We strive to highlight exceptional student work, providing undergraduates and graduates at BU and around the world with a platform to share their writing with a general philosophical readership. We are dedicated to helping students bridge the gap between the kind of writing that is expected of them in their coursework and the kind of writing that is expected of an academic philosopher. For more information and to attend a general meeting, please contact the editors at arche@bu.edu.

column1: Assisting Refugees through Initiative, Service & Education
column4: A service and education club seeking to improve the lives of those affected by forced displacement. We facilitate service and foster discussions around topics relating to immigrants, refugees, asylum seekers, homeless populations, etc.

The Armenian Student Association (ASA) brings together students who share an interest in Armenian culture, heritage, and community. Our mission is to strengthen cultural identity among Armenian students while also educating the broader campus about Armenian history and traditions. We celebrate our roots through events centered around food, music, dance, and important historical milestones. Located in Boston, home to a vibrant Armenian community, the ASA takes full advantage of local cultural institutions and partnerships. Whether you're looking to connect with your heritage or simply learn more about Armenian culture, the ASA offers a welcoming space for all students to engage, celebrate, and grow together.

The Art History Association is an undergraduate student-run organization. We are open to anyone, regardless of your major or knowledge of art history. Throughout the year, we have some great activities, such as museum visits, themed discussions, and guest speakers. We hold career advising sessions to help those interested in an art-related career decide what to do and how to do it. Through regular e-mails, we keep members up-to-date on art-related events around the city, such as gallery openings, new museum exhibitions, lectures, and more. We also work closely with the Graduate Student Art History Association (GSHAA), CFA Student Government, and the Boston University Art Gallery to keep members informed of these great organizations

The aim of Boston University's Art Club is to create a fostering artistic community where students can engage with one another through different forms of artistic expression. The mission of the group is to provide a safe, stress-free environment where students, from a beginner level to a professional level, can simply do art. Activities would include painting on a tile, going to a museum, painting an article of clothing, etc. We will meet weekly and each week will have a different activity centered around it. You can contact the president of the club with any questions you may have.

Art heals the heart and soul. Visual and performing arts have been used to promote healing and well-being for centuries. We aim to foster a welcoming community that strives to help others through the arts and to bring joy and beauty to those who need it most. We are passionate about giving to organizations that represent the under-served and help those in need in the Greater Boston area. We are also passionate about giving student artists of all skill levels a platform for their work. Our goal is to get as many students with a diversity of interests and majors involved in fulfilling charity events that do not require an extensive time commitment. Art for the Heart facilitates the donation of students' work to raise funds for various charities with our semester art sales. Each semester the e-board selects different charitable causes to collaborate and fundraise for. Into the performing arts and non-visual art forms? We have plans to incorporate as many art forms as possible into the club mission, and are open to hearing all member suggestions! Passionate about the cause but not into the arts? Art for the Heart hosts numerous student-led opportunities which fundraise for or assist the charities and organizations our club collaborates with. Past events have included putting together care packages for local homeless outreach organizations with personalized notes, member-created art prints, and hygiene products purchased from funds raised by our art sales. We welcome all BU students to join the cause to give back while having fun! <3

The Boston University Arts Administration Student Association (AASA) is a Graduate student group that was formed in the spring of 1995 to provide opportunities for social interaction, educational enrichment and career development for Arts Administration students. Our mission is to cultivate a sense of community among Arts Administration students while creating educational enrichment and career development opportunities. As part of this mission, the association works to make new students feel as comfortable and confident as possible from the moment they arrive. AASA can be a valuable instrument in raising the profile of the Arts Administration program among industry professionals, as well as an indispensable resource for developing personal and professional relationships with fellow students. We hope that you will choose to lend your time and talents as active members of AASA as we endeavor to make the association a more visible part of the BU Arts Administration program and the arts community in Boston. We hope to hear from many of you!

The Albanian Student Association is a club in which enriches the already diverse campus of Boston University by bringing together students of Albanian descent or those interested in learning Albanian culture, history, and contemporary issues. The Albanian community is very tightly knit and we believe that students should be able to experience this patriotic and family-oriented environment. We look to provide students from all over the world a place that they can call home, where we provide relationships, advice, and much more.

Welcome to BU Asian American Christian Fellowship! Our mission is to reach out not only to Asian Americans but to anyone who is seeking an open community on campus to understand and live out the message of Jesus Christ. Visit our Facebook page, visit our website, and follow/message us on Instagram @buaacf to learn more!

Asian Baptist Student Koinonia is a Christian fellowship at Boston University that strives to practice exactly that: Christ-centered fellowship best described in the Bible by the Greek word, koinonia. This means you don't have to be Asian or Baptist to join; anyone and everyone is welcome!

Boston University's Asian Student Union (ASU) is an all-inclusive organization that aims to educate members about the different aspects of Asian and Asian American culture. Our goal is to showcase talent in our community, inform the student body of social justice matters that are relevant to our world today, and collaborate with organizations that share a similar vision. Ultimately, we aim to represent our students and foster unity and family within our diverse Asian community and beyond.

column1: Alpha Sigma Kappa - Women in Technical Studies
column4: Alpha Sigma Kappa (ASK) is a sorority dedicated to those pursuing a STEM degree. It is the mission of ASK to provide a supportive community for women in STEM academically, professionally, and socially. ASK is unique in the sense that it is not an organization dedicated towards a particular science but rather fosters an interdisciplinary environment within the sciences. Women of all backgrounds can come together and find common ground over a passion for science while helping each other thrive academically. As a chapter, ASK is hoping to grow over the years at BU; there are many opportunities for women to develop organizational and leadership skills that will be invaluable to them post-graduation. ASK is BU's only women-in-STEM sorority and will foster collaboration between the sciences in a rapidly evolving discipline.

Founded in 1997, Aural Fixation is a treble-voiced a cappella group at Boston University. We perform original arrangements of the best that the music world has to offer. From throwbacks to power ballads and everything in between, we take pride in our ability to find the meaning behind the songs we sing. To us, the act of making music is an opportunity to celebrate each other, while empowering all minoritized groups. Aural Fixation is built upon making great music and life-long friendships. Check us out on YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, and our website!! http://auralfixationbu.com/

The goal of the Autism Spectrum Awareness Association is to increase understanding and acceptance of autism among the Boston University students as well as reduce the stigma and discrimination around the autism spectrum. We want to help educate our peers on the autism spectrum disorder and provide resources for them to further educate themselves. We aim to achieve this by organizing informational meetings/events, fundraising for organizations, and working with other clubs/organizations in order to build a supportive community at Boston University for individuals and communities affected by autism.

BU Baja's goal is to design, manufacture and compete with an off-road Baja vehicle each year. We work to compete each year at the Society of Automotive Engineers' Baja Collegiate Design Competition. These competitions are hosted each year in different locations in the US and attended by teams from universities around the world. Teams at the competition compete against one another in a series of events that test the integrity of the car they built and push it and its driver to their physical limits. Students who participate in BU Baja gain valuable experience in design as well as hands-on work. Students will work with and be trained in SolidWorks, welding, and machining. However, BU Baja is not just a club for engineers - students from all schools can participate. Baja can give students experience in management, finance, and marketing in addition to engineering-related fields. BU Baja is a club for anyone who wants to get real-world experience related to vehicle design, manufacturing, and of course, off-road racing. Interested? Great! Come check us out at our website Build Sessions are held on weekly, Thursdays 6 pm - 9pm and Saturdays 11 am - 4 pm at: Fraunhofer USA CMI15 Saint Mary's Street Brookline, MA 02446, USA

The Dancesport Club at Boston University aims to share its love of ballroom dancing with the student body. At BUDC, we strive to provide a welcoming and encouraging environment for anyone interested in learning more about ballroom dancing. We're open to everyone, whether you are interested in competitive or social dancing, and whether you've been dancing for 10 years or have never stepped on a dancefloor before. We hire professional coaches who teach lessons at varying levels, host showcases and team bonding events, and travel to competitions. Check out our website and social media for more information!

Welcome to the Bangladeshi Student's Association! BSA celebrates and honors the culture of Bangladesh, a thriving nation with a rich cultural history. We are the only Bangladeshi club on campus and encourage not only Bengalis, but all those interested in the culture and traditions to join BSA! Our staple annual event is the Pohela Boishakh (Bengali New Year) which is celebrated by song, dance, and delicious Bengali food. We are always looking for new members, wider audiences, and we welcome all to join!

Best Buddies is a National Organization dedicated to building friendships between people with and without Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities. We meet with students from several high schools in Boston and get together about once a month for different activities such as Friendsgiving, A'Capella concerts, and basketball games. Feel free to email us or contact us on social media if you have any questions about our club or are interested in joining!

Boston University Bhangra is a competitive, all-inclusive bhangra team, founded in 1999, that is dedicated to raising awareness about South Asian culture both on and off campus through a folk Indian dance form, bhangra. The team looks to foster a safe space for members of all genders, ages, and backgrounds to become not just skilled dancers, but moreover, confident artists.

The goal of the Boston University Biobiz club is to provide a community for passionate students to network and explore the nuances of biotech and pharmaceutical companies. We want to be able to provide mentorship and guidance for those planning on entering the industry through both the business and science perspective. We want to foster an environment where there is a fluidity between the STEM and business fields so that students in both areas can see how intertwined both areas are. We also want to bring more awareness to this field in the Boston University community as an interdisciplinary area that more people should explore.

The Mission of the BMES is to build and support the biomedical engineering community, locally, nationally and internationally, with activities designed to communicate recent advances, discoveries, and inventions; promote education and professional development; and integrate the perspectives of the academic, medical, governmental, and business sectors.
BIPOC Mental Health Collective is a communal space for racial minorities to nurture their mental health by sharing experiences and resources.

Boston University's Black Business Student Association (BBSA) is an active resource on campus that bridges the opportunity gap for students of color through professional development and educational programming. Our undergraduate members gain a wide breadth of career advice, corporate experience, and a supportive community network of current students, alumni, professionals, and corporate partners. BBSA strives to also educate on the value of diversity and be a strong advocate of diversity and inclusion both within the Questrom School of Business and the greater Boston University Community.

column1: BlackBox: Boston University's Black Film Society
column4: BlackBox is Boston University's Black film society. BlackBox invites Black and P.O.C filmmakers to pitch stories that might be scarier to share with those that don't have the experience of being in the minority. This safe space will not only provide a home away from home to those that might be struggling to find their community in BU's massive student population, but facilitate networking opportunities, which is essential for a career field like film and television production. BlackBox wants to create a space where Black students can discover and develop interests and skills in the film space.

column1: National Society of Black Women in Medicine
column4: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine, as a national student and professional based organization, thereby dedicate itself to the development of intensive programs for increasing the participation of Black women in the fields of healthcare and science. These programs will be initiated both within and outside the institution community and will serve to strengthen relationships between the professional industry and the black community. Members of this organization are encouraged to join and participate in their individual professional societies. This organization will endeavor to provide general counseling to all members. Applications are open in the Fall of each academic year.

We are an inclusive, multifaceted community dedicated to equal education in the web3 space. We aim to foster creativity, build a diverse network, and shape a decentralized future together. Through research, development, and building companies - BU Blockchain aims to act as a springboard for all students to unleash their potential in the field.

Board Games Club is a catch-all organization for all your non-digital gaming needs. If it can be played on a table (or even not), someone in our club will be happy to play it with you! You can also join our mailing list or click here to join our discord to keep up with any future events, meetings, and information related to BGC. You can also follow us on Instagram at @buboardgames. (1) General meetings are held 7-11pm on Thursdays and are open to BU community members and members of the public with BU connections (i.e., current students, staff, or alumni). Up-to-date information on club meeting location is sent shortly before meetings, both through the mailing list and through Discord. During general meetings, members are free to play from the library of games maintained by the club or to bring games from their own personal collections. These games typically range from lighter party games (Codenames, Spyfall, Avalon, etc.) to medium and heavy weight games (Betrayal, Power Grid, Terraforming Mars, etc.). ??2) We try to host Trivia Nights, Escape Rooms, and Murder Mystery Events yearly plus many more events to keep our community engaged and entertained. If any of those events sound interesting to you, you should follow us or join our discord and we will keep you updated! (3) Pitch nights for Tabletop Role Playing Games are held periodically, typically at the beginning of each semester. These events are open to all experience levels and gaming backgrounds and are a great way to jump into the hobby. Interested DM/GMs pitch their campaigns to interested players and are matched into parties based on preferences, schedules, and commitment levels. Other TTRPG offerings are held throughout the semester based on member interest. ??? (4) Card game specific events and meetings are held contingent on member interest. Card games such as Magic: The Gathering, Yu-gi-oh, Netrunner, and Pokemon TCG are often played at general meetings alongside traditional board games, and tournaments for the most popular of these games are held when possible. ??? If you are interested in any other non-digital gaming categories (such as Wargaming, longer/legacy games like Diplomacy, traditional games like Mahjong and Go, etc.), BGC is happy to work with you to promote and organize related events or generate interest at general meetings. Feel free to contact us if you have something specific you'd like to play.

BU on Beat is a student organization dedicated to promoting the vibrant culture of house music within our university community. Our mission is to provide a supportive and inclusive environment where aspiring DJs and electronic music enthusiasts can come together to learn, collaborate, and share their passion for house music. Through collaboration and mutual learning, we aim to empower our members of varying levels to develop their skills, express their creativity through mixing events, and contribute positively to the local music scene. Anyone is welcome, beginner or otherwise!

BostonHacks is a collection of students who work towards promoting the hackathon spirit within and outside of BU. Our members are involved in web-, mobile-, and hardware-based development, and come from many different colleges within BU. We cater to students of all skill levels and majors and foster an educational environment where members collaborate and help each other. Our main focus is organizing BU's most prominent annual hackathon in November, where students from all across the country can come to innovate and create projects for 24 hours. Outside the hackathon, we host workshops to help the BU public learn and develop new skills. Sometimes, these workshops will consist of free food and swag!

The Boston Political Review is Boston University's premier political publication founded in 2014.??We are a nonpartisan student-run platform for the BU community to express its voice and to give our readers a refreshing source of unbiased information. The BPR typically consists of five sections: Global Politics, U.S. Politics, Local Politics, Social & Business. and Health & Science. ??Our writing staff strikes a harmonious balance between a typical news story and an academic paper, as their articles contain elements of traditional student journalism and analytical deep dives. The BPR is committed to creating an informed student body and maintaining a publication with integrity that upholds the key tenets of student journalism.

Each semester, the BU BosTones brings a fresh energy to the Boston a cappella scene. We are a co-ed group of undergraduates belting out sizzling arrangements and killer harmonies. We have placed first at the Northeast International Collegiate A Cappella semi-final, becoming the first international finalist from BU since 2005. We perform a winter and spring concert each year, plus benefit concerts, guest appearances, campus events, and more! Going forward, we hope to soon record our next studio album and continue to represent Boston University on an international level. Check out our website: thebostones.com, or email us at thebostones@gmail.com! We'd love to hear from you - the bostones!

With 450+ student organizations, it's easy to pursue a favorite hobby or get a taste of something different. We'll help you find students who share your interests—or get the ball rolling with you to create a new group. If you're looking to dovetail your pastimes with your long-term goals, a chat with us can help. Drop by and share what makes you tick, or check us out on Facebook and Twitter.

column1: Arab Students in Business at BU

column4: Hospital blood shortage is a critical, nationwide issue that jeopardizes the care of countless patients. This issue is complex and multifaceted, however, two central components are a lack of diversity in donors and a low number of young blood donors. We seek to educate our generation on the nature of the blood shortage and motivate people to take action. Our organization builds meaningful connections with our local youth, and through this, works to increase awareness and engagement of potential donors. By collaborating closely with local blood centers, encouraging people to donate there, and organizing blood drives here on our campus, we seek to empower and support our nearby hospitals. Through the formation of a sustainable blood supply to these centers, a lasting and impactful relationship is strengthened within the community.

The name "BPM" not only represents our college organization but also carries a deeper meaning. BPM stands for "Beats Per Minute," which is a fundamental element in music. It refers to the tempo or speed at which a musical piece is played, providing the rhythmic foundation that keeps the music moving and grooving. In choosing this name, we emphasize our dedication to delivering energetic and captivating performances that resonate with our audience and keep their hearts racing in time with the beat. In doing so, we help students who want to learn how to write their original songs and produce music. We do this by providing music software (FL Studio, Cubase, etc.), hosting information sessions open to BU students, and helping students one-on-one during weekly meeting sessions. We also match members (singers) with producers to collaborate and make their own music together. Second, we host yearly and semester-based music performances to provide stage presence and experience. We perform a total of 15-20 songs, with more than half of the songs being fully original pieces from our singer-songwriters, producers, sound engineers, and instrumentalists. We host busking performances across the Boston area to gain more stage experience, have fun, and collaborate with other Korean organizations to promote music. The genres change based on the individual preferences of our artists, but the most popular ones are Pop, K-Hiphop, and R&B. In conjunction with that, we collaborate with other Korean organizations such as KOMMA, QK, and KISA to host events that teach students how easy and fun it can be to produce their own music. At BPM, we believe in the power of music to transcend boundaries and connect people from diverse backgrounds. Through our performances, we strive to showcase the vibrant sounds of Korean music and culture, while also exploring and celebrating various genres. Our repertoire spans a wide range of musical styles, ensuring that there's something for everyone to enjoy and appreciate.
We are a professional co-ed biology fraternity that provides leadership opportunities, expands social networks, and generates a community of equally driven students.

The Boston University Brazilian Association (aka, BUBA) fosters Brazilian cultural appreciation and exploration by organizing exciting and engaging activities. Built on a welcoming philosophy, this club is open to Brazilians and non-Brazilians, speakers of Portuguese and non-speakers alike.

The Breathe BU Wellness Club exists to create a yoga-focused inclusive, uplifting space where Boston University students can explore wellness in all its forms??hysical, mental, and emotional. From yoga flows and strength workouts to mindful journaling and an online platform, we aim to empower students to build sustainable, joyful habits that support their well-being both on and off campus.

BridgeBU is the Boston University chapter of BridgeUSA, a student-led organization that aims to combat political polarization by fostering a political culture of respect and open-mindedness on college campuses nationwide. Here at BU, we hope to "bridge" divides on campus by hosting discussions and other events that give all students a platform to voice their opinions on a wide range of issues and current events. We stop trying to win short-term battles and look forward to finding long-term solutions.

The Student Activities Office is here to serve the student organization experience by supporting officers, leaders, and general members, in their work within their student organization. SAO organizes trainings, development workshops, financial support, and more for student organization leaders. SAO also plans and manages the Weeks of Welcome events that welcome new and returning students to campus in the beginning of each semester. At the end of each year SAO plans Senior Week to celebrate the achievements of the senior class and the community they have made on campus.

Campus Closet (formerly BU Closet) is Boston University's shared closet, empowering students to become conscious consumers through free, sustainable, and accessible clothing swaps. We regularly host clothing drives and swaps, offering students a chance to connect, collaborate, and engage in circular consumption. More than a resource for sustainable fashion, Campus Closet is a platform for creative expression and community building, bridging campus organizations to foster inclusivity and environmental stewardship.

The Boston University Himalayan Student Association, BUHSA, will promote community for Himalayan students to expand inclusivity on Boston University's campus. HSA will partake in cultural events, peaceful demonstrations, and educational events to educate others about Himalayan culture. Students can look forward to events such as our Annual MOMO Night, food events, and cultural movie screenings. We welcome students of all backgrounds to diversify and embrace a new community at BU!

The Boston University Chapter of BU Naturally founded April 29th, 2019. We are a natural hair based organization that promotes diversity, inclusivity, and love of all natural hair types on campus and in the community.

The Nigerian Students Association of Boston University is committed to fostering a community of Nigerian students on campus. It serves as a home away from home for those wanting to express their culture and explore their roots, while also serving as an open space for others to learn about the culture. It will also serve as a space to educate members of issues Nigeria is currently facing in hopes of promoting social activism among the community. The goal for BU NSA is to create a safe environment for students to share their love and appreciation for Nigerian culture while celebrating our similarities and differences as university students. We also aim to foster an open and accepting learning environment to give the Black Boston community a platform to elevate their voices.

Quiz Bowl is a competition where teams go head-to-head to answer trivia questions first and try to score the most points against the other team. Boston University Quiz Bowl club is an organization where people who are interested in academic trivia can come together to discuss their favorite topics, practice, and prepare for Quiz Bowl tournaments. Information about local or online tournaments will be discussed and practice/study sessions will be held at meetings. The club is open to anyone and no prior experience of Quiz Bowl is required. The mission of the Boston University Quiz Bowl club is to create a friendly environment where people can have fun competing against each other, study/learn for Quiz Bowl, and compete in intercollegiate tournaments.

BU Students for Israel (BUSI) is a student organization dedicated to educating and engaging students in Israeli culture, politics, and history. We host Israel-related events and speakers, lead meaningful discussions on a host of topics, and celebrate Jewish holidays as a community of diverse backgrounds and perspectives. As the only pro-Israel club on campus, we are committed to bringing a wide breadth of political and cultural ideas to the broader Boston University community, while supporting the Jewish homeland. ??,https://linktr.ee/studentsforisrael,https://www.instagram.com/buforisrael/,https://www.facebook.com/IsraeliClubBU/,,,1,success
