By participating in the F1Tenth Club, students not only develop technical skills but also cultivate essential soft skills such as teamwork, problem-solving, and communication. Our club fosters an inclusive and supportive environment, encouraging members to explore their interests, take calculated risks, and learn from their failures. Ultimately, the F1Tenth Autonomous Racing Club at Boston University aims to inspire the next generation of innovators and pioneers in the field of autonomous systems, contributing to the advancement of cutting-edge technologies that will shape the future of transportation, robotics, and beyond.

Founded in January 2022 and reformed in September 2024, the core of Fabrio has continued to be a hub for creatives to prioritize sustainability and ethical work within all forms of art. Our collective allows sustainable ideas to be conceptualized, nurtured, and brought to physical form. In our context, the term fa·brio is defined as breathing life into an idea sustainably and ethically.

The Fashion and Retail Association (F&R) of Boston University is committed to building a pipeline to the fashion and retail industry through a variety of events and opportunities. It is the ideal outlet for undergraduate BU students who are interested in both creative and professional opportunities in the workforce. Since it was founded in Spring 2004, F&R has grown into a thriving community with over 100 students involved to this day. We are currently in the process of rebranding the association to promote a more inclusive and professional space for students to express themselves and showcase the influence fashion and retail has on campus. Every year, F&R has a calendar packed with events ranging from professional development panels featuring industry experts, a student-run fashion show, guest speakers, company partnerships, and more! These events open the opportunity for students to not only express their creativity but also build a community of like-minded people and show the university all of the hidden talent it has. Our weekly general meetings promote a safe space through activities ranging from educational games that spark conversation, like Kahoot and Jeopardy, to professional development workshops, like Linkedin, cover letter, and resume building. Don't forget to check out our website for blog posts on the latest fashion news and to learn more about what we do.

BU Fatakada is Boston University's premier co-ed Garba-Raas team, featuring top dancers at BU who proudly share their culture with the Boston University community. Garba-Raas, originating from the Indian state of Gujarat, is a traditional folk dance style that has evolved into a competitive dance form due to the efforts of South Asian-American students over the past two decades. We aim to enrich the BU community through our dance and uphold BU's longstanding presence within the national collegiate Garba-Raas community, as one of the oldest Garba-Raas teams in the circuit.

We are the Boston University chapter of the FeelGood youth movement, a collective of student-run social enterprises that raise money to alleviate world hunger & global poverty, one grilled cheese at a time. Every Tuesday & Thursday from 9-11pm, we partner with Bay State Underground, BU's East Campus late night dining service. Here, we have a space to prepare, cook, and sell various grilled cheese sandwiches to students via the GrubHub app. Volunteering can be one-time, low-commitment, but if you vibe with us, consider joining our general meetings! All proceeds are donated to The Hunger Project, our parent organization, to be invested in high-need communities across the globe. FeelGood BU represents an opportunity for students to develop entrepreneurial skills, gain volunteer hours, and have fun in a down-to-earth, extremely cool & funny community. Join our Discord here!
Fenway Campus Hall Council is meant to support and create community on the Fenway Campus

Mabuhay! Welcome to BUFSA! BUFSA is an organization which advocates and celebrates the richness of the Filipino heritage! Through community involvement and education, BUFSA aims to expand our club's core values to the rest of BU students, faculty, staff, and alumni: diversity, inclusivity, acceptance, embracing and sharing Filipino culture. BUFSA is home for all students from all walks of life, and are always welcoming more members to join our family! A few weekly and annual events we have include: Fam Din: at 6PM/7PM on various days and in various locations TBA in the weekly newsletter. Dance Practice for Upcoming Shows (Traditional and Modern): Learn dances from Tinikling to hip hop and everything in between. Everyone's invited, no experience needed! Practices are on weekends, time and location TBA. Halo-Halloween: Members dress up in costume and watch our annual Halloween video, meet new people and participate in our costume contest! We incorporate our love for food by making halo-halo, a Philippine dessert of shaved ice and a variety of different toppings (jellies, fruits etc) and enjoy a night of fun and friends! ISA: The World Is One: A cherished tradition, ISA is our annual and BU's longest running multicultural show that aims to show the BU community and Greater Boston Area the beauty that comes with diversity, and the amazing talents different cultures and communities of BU has to offer. Speaker Series: our annual speaker series is where we invite different Filipinos paving the way in their fields to speak of their experience and share insight and encouragement that they may have for our students. BUFSA always strives to showcase the Filipino culture and the values rooted in it, like community, resilience, and love. We hope to share these with you, and see you soon!

BUFS is dedicated to bringing you the best movies that the world has to offer, whether it's an intense foreign drama or lighthearted comedy. With an emphasis on laid-back meetings, screenings, and discussion, BUFS is as much a social club as it is a movie club. BUFS welcomes film majors, film fans, or even anyone just mildly interested in movies; all are welcome! So come join us this year: watch some movies and have some fun! Please email us at thebufilmsociety@gmail.com so we can put you on our email list! We meet weekly on Wednesdays at 7pm.

column1: FilmBiz: Boston University?? Entertainment Business Club
column4: FilmBiz is Boston University's first student organization dedicated to students interested in careers within the business and management areas of the entertainment industry (film, television, theater, music, etc). Our mission is to educate students about often-overlooked opportunities in management and behind-the-scenes roles that intersect the worlds of entertainment and business. To achieve our mission, we provide professional events such as industry professional panelists, career workshops, networking events, and social events.

The BU Finance and Investment Club offers all students at Boston University an insight into the world of finance and an opportunity to learn by practical experience. The Club hosts interactive tutorials that explore topics to an extent above and beyond the undergraduate and even the MBA level. They also host the University's only undergraduate live investment fund with 1.1 million assets under management, sourced largely from alumni donations and internal appreciation. Your research through the club will determine real money investment decisions for our portfolio. Members graduate full of hands-on experience and with a network of contacts within the industry. For additional information, please go to our website and sign up for the mailing list (on the home page). Feel free to request membership on the engage website, but please also sign up for our mailing list. Contact buinvest@bu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

BU Financial Modeling Club's primary goal is to bridge the technical gap between formal education and the skills needed to land a job in the finance industry. The club is open to all whether you want to go into private equity, investment banking, or just learn more about excel! BUFMC's peer-led weekly meetings, and mentorship pairings with alumni and upperclassmen at top companies such as Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, and many more ensure that students are equipped with all of the tools needed to land a top role.

Purpose: FinTech BU stands to raise awareness and opportunities to the Boston University community on the new and exciting field of financial technologies and raise awareness on the wave of disruptive technologies the finance world is undergoing. Mission: We aim at integrating FinTech BU and its members with the world of financial technologies through partnerships with universities, companies and other fintech related institutions. This initiative will be supported through info sessions, guest speaker lectures, annual conferences and the BU FinTech Accelerator. Vision: We see FinTech BU as a hub for disruptors and creative thinkers who want to change the way everyday people go about the world of finance; a world currently controlled by large corporations and central banks. We want to provide a space for collaborators to meet and have the chance to work together in projects to revamp the world of finance.

column1: First Generation and/or Low Income Partnership
column4: FLIP @ BostonU Description FLIP (First-Generation Low Income Partnership) @ BostonU aims to support our school's first-generation and/or low-income (FGLI) students. The purpose of FLIP @ BostonU is three-fold: first, to build a community on campus for students who identify as FGLI; second, to create resources and work to maximize equal access to resources for those students who need them; finally, to advocate for and implement institutional change with the help of the institution. FLIP @ BostonU is also a chapter of FLIP National, a national nonprofit whose core tenet is centering student advocacy and the student's voice. FLIP National outlines seven target areas in which all FGLI issues and solutions fall, including those at Boston University: awareness and visibility, academic development, housing insecurity, food insecurity, professional development, student wellbeing, and community building, and financial support. With this partnership, we join a nationwide network of support and innovation consisting of FLIP National's twenty other chapters, as well as the greater platform of FGLI and higher education nonprofits. Through our parent organization, we have access to their existing partnerships and initiatives, including a laptop lending library, FGLI conferences, and FGLI class confession pages. We work closely with the Newbury Center, the First-Generation center on campus, to build community amongst First-Generation and/or Low-Income students on campus, connect students with resources at BU and in Boston, put on programming that meets the needs of students (i.e. academic/professional development, financial resources, mental health, etc.) and generally provide support to students in whatever way they need to help them be successful at BU. In the past we have done student panels with prospective and admitted students, professional panels, professional headshots, study nights, social events (i.e. game nights, succulent decorating, scavenger hunts, museum trips, etc.), discussions about our (intersecting) identities and more. If you're interested in learning more about us you can join our mailing list here: https://forms.gle/9eBcFpxPujMtu1LH7

FORGE Design Studios is Boston University's pre-professional, student-led design community. Our mission is to "forge" a new design community at Boston University, where students of all backgrounds are able to learn and design together. Through our various events and programs, we bridge the gap between emerging designers and the industry. Our programming includes: • FORGE Labs: a summer-long program that connects students with client-based design projects including brand design, graphic design, and UX/UI design. • Design workshops: we help you learn essential design through our workshops. Past ones include Adobe InDesign, Photoshop, Intro to UI/UX Design, and more. • Pre-professional programming: join us for career panels, professional development workshops, and networking events. Learn more about us by following our social media or visiting our website.Join our Slack channel! Sign up for our newsletter!

BU Forté, formerly known as the BU Sweethearts, is a tight-knit group that sing and speak up “loud and proud” for what they believe in. Forté strives to create a fun and inclusive space for all women, non-binary, genderqueer and gender non-conforming people who are passionate about music. They stay busy with rehearsing, planning diversity and inclusion conferences, busking on the streets, fundraising, recording music and, most importantly, goofing off and having fun together! Forté's sound reflects the diversity of its members who come from various ethnic backgrounds and have an array of passions in addition to singing. Together, these unique individuals have shaped Forté into becoming the one-of-a-kind a Cappella group it is today.

We aim to warmly welcome the French-speaking and French-learning community at Boston University, regardless of their level of fluency, to Boston and to the University and to facilitate their integration and provide them with support. We also aim to organize social events and to help students of French with their progress in placing them into contact with other French speakers and by encouraging them to practice the language in various settings such as conferences, debates, lectures, social gatherings, and general meetings. The French Club strives to foster an open-minded and inclusive community on BU campus and on our digital media. We welcome all francophones and we love to hear your feedback and constructive criticism to keep our club vibrant and growing. In the spirit of a safe and friendly environment, we do not welcome disrespectful comments and behaviors, in person or online, and therefore we reserve the right to ask anyone who shows inappropriate or aggressive conduct to not attend events and/or participate on our online platforms.

Established in 1993, Fusion is one of Boston University's dance troupes. Comprised of approximately 30 talented BU students, Fusion acts as a source of creative expression and personal growth through dance. Fusion provides a space for its members, members of the BU community, and beyond to grow and learn as dancers through consistent training and various performance opportunities. By constantly encouraging ingenuity, originality, and a sense of community, Fusion fosters lasting relationships between strong and versatile dancers.

BU Gaming Club is all about casual and competitive gaming. We welcome all types of gamers, whether you play one hour a week or twenty. We host a variety of fun events and hold meetings every week. Join us and make friends while improving your gameplay! We also have competitive esports teams across a variety of games. Join our Discord server to learn more!discord.gg/BostonU

The Gamma Phi Beta sorority's mission is to promote the highest type of womanhood and build confident women of character. The Delta chapter at Boston University has over 130 members from all over the world. We seek to promote the highest type of womanhood by living our lives out by our four core values of love, labor, learning, and loyalty.

The German Culture Club is a Boston University organization open to everyone, created to help all participating individuals learn about what it means to be German both here in Boston and elsewhere. By joining this club, members will gain knowledge and participate in cultural traditions as well as understand more about the country itself, its history and language through meetings and organized social events. Regardless of their reasons for joining the German Culture Club, members will have an opportunity to connect with students pursuing a major/minor, those exploring their heritage, and newcomers who simply have an interest in the exciting culture and traditions of the German people. This club strives to create a fun and welcoming environment by bringing a piece of German-speaking countries to the Boston area. Join our newsletter to receive updates https://mailchi.mp/364f55b1be48/german-culture-club-signup

We are a nationwide female weight lifting organization with four core values: strength, boldness, people, integrity, and visionary. We provide resources and community for women of all backgrounds and fitness levels. At a campus level, we host workout events, community events, workshops, and informational meetings led by certified personal trainers, nutritionists, and more.

Boston University Global China Connection dedicates to create a career development platform and a professional networking environment for BU students through hosting career skill training sessions and professional summits/panels with corporations around the world. The goal of Boston University Global China Connection is a major gateway between Boston University and China. Boston University Global China Connection will partner with 30 other Global China Connections chapters worldwide to provide opportunities for BU students to network with their peers who share a mutual interest.

Global Brigades is an international nonprofit that empowers communities around the world to meet their health and economic goals through university volunteers. Since water is fundamental for everyday activities, without sufficient clean water the health of entire communities is affected. The engineering chapter focuses on the design and implementation of water systems in rural communities to address these dire needs of families that have little or no access to clean water. Each year GEngB goes on a Brigade in country and/ or virtually to work with communities and local experts to design and implement a clean water system. We also focus on local outreach and attend volunteering events in the Boston area that are involved with food banks, trash clean ups and much more! Join us and look through our website: https://bugengb.wixsite.com/website

Global Medical Brigades is a secular, international, student-operated volunteer organization whose mission is to provide sustained health care to underserved communities throughout the world. Global Medical Brigades is a part of the larger organization known as Global Brigades, which is the world's largest student-led global health and development initiative. Our BU chapter recruits student volunteers and medical professionals, gathers medicine and other supplies in order to lead a week-long brigade. Partnering with GMB and local healthcare professionals, we will be working to provide medical consults, medications, public health education, dental and optometry services, and more to hundreds of community members who otherwise have limited healthcare options. This is important hands-on work that highlights our organization's commitment to global health equity. Our brigades are essential to fulfill our mission of providing sustained health care to underserved communities throughout the world.

column1: Global Tea Club at Boston University
column4: From the sweet tea of the Southern United States, to British afternoon tea, to the Japanese tea ceremony, and to Moroccan mint tea and beyond, ??ea??s an essential part of life in many different cultures around the world. The aim of this organization is to mutually come to a deeper understanding of the world's various cultures through the lens of tea from around the globe. This includes a focus on tea education and appreciation within a culture and between cultures, such as the different varieties of tea in Chinese tea culture and how the Chinese tea ceremony varies from the tea ceremonies present in Japan and Korea. We hope to create a space for people passionate about tea to be able to comfortably try tea from different facets of the world and gain knowledge of various aspects of different cultures that may otherwise feel inaccessible. In addition, we hope to be a conduit through which all members can share and educate other members on their own culture through tea. In this way, creating an organization where mutual continued learning is possible and sustainable, allowing members to gain a more well rounded understanding of Boston University's diverse student body in the process.

Graphic Medicine Club is a student-led organization that explores the intersection between the medium of graphic narratives and the discourse surrounding healthcare. We aim to create a diverse community of BU students who are fans of comics and medicine in order to spread awareness of the field of graphic medicine by facilitating student collaborations with other student clubs, authors, artists, and art therapists. At the Graphic Medicine Club, students will learn more about graphic medicine's use as a therapeutic and educational tool for patients and healthcare providers, and gain opportunities to share their own experiences through art.

column1: GroupIRean: Korean Diplomatic and Political Association
column4: In 2010, the founder of GroupIRean came together to provide a venue for students at Boston University to explore international relations, social and political affairs of the relatively under-studied region, the Korean peninsula. The name GroupIRean indicates that we have gathered as a ‘group', with passion in International Relations (‘IR') of Korea. As a member of this organization, you will have the opportunity to explore the minor region of Korea in depth through open discussion sections, our think tank project (Information Center of Essence), through attending and hosting guest lectures on global diplomatic issues.

Guerrilla Marketing Society (GMS) provides marketing consulting services to local businesses by offering them a marketing campaign plan for their business specifically using guerrilla marketing tactics. Our past partnerships include Expedia, DedCool, Touchland, YiFang, Spotify, and more. The mission of GMS is to contribute to the education of BU students through hands on experience and informative workshops. GMS members are given the opportunity to function as small, non-profit consulting groups for local companies. Students will gain experience in consulting, teamwork, researching, and creating captivating guerrilla marketing strategies. ALL MAJORS ARE WELCOME. For additional information, please contact us at bugms@bu.edu or visit our website at https://www.bostongms.com/.

Background: Hack4Impact is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that was founded by University of Pennsylvania.Hack4Impact has many chapters at other universities, including Columbia University, Georgia Tech, and Boston University. The mission of Hack4Impact is to develop software for other nonprofits to meet their social and humanitarian needs.

Founded in 2021, HackHardware is an organization that's focus is to provide students the opportunity to innovate and help in the creation of the next big thing! Every month, HackHardware will be hosting events such as tutorials in software such as Solidworks and AutoCAD, beginner & advanced workshops on using Arduino, and even collaboration with other Engineering & Computer Science clubs at Boston University. Alongside this, HackHardware will have an annual free Hardware-focused hackathon, where students from Boston University and other local universities can create their own innovations based on the tracks and limitations provided! HackHardware is open for students of all years, majors and skill levels, and focuses on catering to our innovational spirit!

Hapa: a word of Hawaiian descent that defines a person of partial Asian or Pacific Islander descent. The word “hapa” is used globally among the mixed-race community. We use it to embrace our identities, which can prove to be difficult in a world where many expect us to choose just one race. “Do you feel more Asian or more white?” is a question that is all too familiar to many of our executive board. Why can't we be both? These questions led us to the formation of HAPA, Boston University's Half-Asian People's Association, in order to create a community where students of any mixed-race background can convene to form bonds with others who have shared similar experiences. Though the group's name states Half-Asian, we welcome any student who has struggled with their racial identity or is simply looking for a group of friends. Through bi-monthly on-campus meetings, we aim to foster a community where mixed-race students feel comfortable and understood. We already attend a school where students hail from numerous backgrounds and cultures, and HAPA hopes to further expand the meaning of diversity and inclusivity at Boston University.

The Hawaii Cultural Association aims to educate the Boston University community about Hawaiian culture through sharing our foods, stories, and performances. We help create a home-away-from-home for students from Hawaii, helping them adjust to college life in Boston. Join us in spreading the aloha spirit!

What is the relationship between law and medicine? How do insurance companies and doctors play a role in nationwide healthcare? What is the connection between economics and public health? How will change be implemented to address healthcare disparities? Healthcare Improvement Inc. seeks to answer these questions. This is an interdisciplinary student club that connects the seemingly at-conflict fields of medicine, law, economics, and public health. Our mission is to improve community healthcare and advocate for national healthcare improvements, with an emphasis on patient care.

Hearts for the Homeless (H4H) serves one of the most vulnerable populations by providing education on multiple health risk factors, monitoring of blood pressure measurements, and donating health care and prevention resources to people experiencing homelessness in Boston. Through partnering with local shelters and community health clinics, H4H seeks to reduce the prevalence of hypertension among these individuals. Aside from serving the community, H4H educates its members on cardiovascular disease and its impact on the community through volunteer experience. This organization shapes our members into compassionate leaders and spreads awareness of cardiovascular disease to underprivileged communities in Boston. Want to get involved? Join our (email) mailing list here: https://tinyurl.com/5299rj54 Check out our website here: https://sites.bu.edu/h4hboston/ Follow us on instagram: @h4hboston

The BUHA goal is to enlighten the Boston University campus and the greater Boston area with the language, art, culture, history, politics, economies, beauty and majesty of modern and classical Hellenism. We welcome and counsel all new hellenic students!

Helping Hands for the Homeless aims to spread awareness about homelessness in Boston and provide necessary resources to the homeless in the Boston area. Members of this organization have volunteered at local shelters and soup kitchens such as St. Francis House, Pine Street Inn, The New England Center and Home for Veterans, Rosie's Place, Boston Rescue Mission and Sunday's Bread, helping to prepare and serve meals to those living there. We have also worked with several organizations to fund-raise and to collect supplies that will be distributed to those who need them most.

Her Campus is the leading media platform dedicated to empowering college women around the globe. Founded by and for college women, Her Campus is your ultimate destination for navigating the unique experiences that come with this transformative stage in life, whether it's curating the trendiest dorm on campus, landing your dream internship, or prioritizing your mental health while balancing a crazy-packed schedule. Her Campus Boston University is a community that uplifts, informs, and connects college women on topics like pop culture, wellness, style, politics, health, and more. Check us out online at HerCampus.com/BU for more information. Follow us on Instagram or Twitter: @HerCampusBU.

Welcome to Her Financial Future @ Boston University (@herfinancialfuturebu)! We started our organization as a safe space to teach all women and non-binary individuals (in all majors) about personal finance and investing. Despite there being great Questrom student organizations dedicated to stock trading, finance, financial modeling, and investing, we noticed a need for a club to teach women about personal finance and the basics of investing. So many of these clubs are open to all, but are heavily male-dominated, and it can be very daunting to join if you are a woman or if you aren't a Questrom major. We don't want HFF to feel intimidating to join at all. HFF is a safe space for women and non-binary individuals to learn more about how to sustain themselves financially and just about personal finance in general. In the Fall 2025 semester, we will be hosting bi-weekly workshops starting 9/9/25, and we will notify attendees of upcoming workshops, speaker events, or networking events via our Instagram (@herfinancialfuturebu) and via our newsletter. Sign up here! tinyurl.com/HFFbu2025 We hope to see you this semester! :)

column1: herNetwork - Boston University Women in Business
column4: herNetwork is the Women in Business club which serves as a networking and mentoring group for motivated and passionate undergraduate BU students. We welcome all genders and majors. With our motto "Women Mean Business" we aim to build a strong and empowering community that invests in ourselves and in one another. Through corporate events, speaker panels, workshops, and our annual Spring Conference we strive to inspire, connect and educate our members in order to help them start a successful career. Please email us at herntwrk@bu.edu to join our mailing list and stay informed of our events and career information. We have many exciting things coming your way! Also, please like our Facebook page herNetwork Boston University and follow our Instagram @hernetworkbu. It will serve as a platform for members to interact with one another and share their thoughts on current issues and our latest events.

BUHPC is a student group hosted under the College of Engineering and is open to the entire BU community. The primary goal of this club is to enable students to learn about High Performance Computing and get hands on experience with in-house computing clusters. The objectives of the club are: 1. To form an interdisciplinary team of motivated undergraduates who will compete at various international student HPC competitions and conferences. 2. To motivate all students to learn about the applications and importance of HPC with as much in-depth technical and hands-on experience as possible. and 3. To inform and educate on the topic of HPC and how it intersects with AI to a broad range of people.

Hillel, the center for Jewish life on campus, is the largest, most exciting, and most versatile organization at Boston University. Students work hard to build connections and strengthen relationships with other campus communities. They have made Hillel an integral part of BU's social, cultural, educational, political, and religious life.

Boston University Hong Kong Student Association is student-run organization dedicated to promoting greater Cantonese culture on campus. Through events such as Dim Sum outings and Chinese New Year celebrations, our members can get a glimpse of Hong Kong in the city of Boston. We also collaborate with other cultural organizations and our alumni to highlight inclusivity and diversity, connecting our members with the larger BU population. We aim to provide opportunities for people of all interests and identities to come together and become a part of our growing community. If you have a passion for the Cantonese culture, miss “Home Kong” a little, or simply want to contribute to our mission, please consider BUHKSA!

The goal of the organization is to introduce students to the hospitality industry through networking events, hotel and restaurant tours, and general meetings. The club aims to create a community within the School of Hospitality beyond the classroom. This organization is open to all undergraduate students at Boston University. (Formerly the BU American Hotel & Lodging Association Student Chapter)

BU IEEE Student Chapter and IEEE-HKN Kappa Sigma Chapter At Boston University, the IEEE Student Chapter and the IEEE-HKN Kappa Sigma Chapter merge to form a vibrant community known as BU IEEE, under the guidance of Professor Min-Chang Lee. Our association, BU IEEE, is deeply integrated with the IEEE Boston Section, benefiting from Professor Lee's leadership roles within various IEEE societies and committees. Originating from the establishment of BU HKN by Professor Lee in 2001, our IEEE-HKN chapter evolved and was officially reinstated as the Kappa Sigma Chapter in 2016, marking a significant milestone in our history. Together, we are officially recognized and supported by Boston University's Student Activities Office and the ECE Department, enabling us to offer a range of enriching activities including lectures, workshops, and social events, specifically tailored for ECE students from Freshmen to Seniors. BU IEEE Membership and Activities Membership to the BU IEEE Student Chapter is open to all ECE students, offering a platform for academic and professional development through a diverse range of activities. Our engagements extend beyond campus, connecting members with alumni and industry professionals to foster networking and mentorship opportunities. The IEEE-HKN Honor Society, an elite segment of our chapter, distinguishes itself by inviting students who exhibit exceptional academic achievement and embody the IEEE-HKN ideals of Scholarship, Character, and Attitude. Membership to IEEE-HKN is a prestigious honor, recognizing students who not only excel academically but also contribute positively to the community and the field of electrical and electronics engineering. Engagement and Induction Throughout the year, our chapter collaborates with the department to identify and invite students who meet the rigorous IEEE-HKN criteria for membership. Candidates undergo a period of engagement with the chapter, allowing us to assess their commitment to the core principles of IEEE-HKN. The culmination of this process is our annual induction ceremony, where selected candidates are formally welcomed into the IEEE-HKN Honor Society. This induction not only symbolizes academic excellence but also opens doors to exclusive IEEE-HKN events and networking opportunities, both locally and globally. Connect With Us For more information about the IEEE Student Chapter or the IEEE-HKN Honor Society at Boston University, please reach out to us at ieee@bu.edu. We are committed to fostering a supportive and dynamic community for students passionate about electrical and electronics engineering and related fields.

In 1981, a group of Indians at BU came together with a vision: a student group at Boston University allowing people from all over the Boston area to meet and network. Over the last 37 years, the Boston University India Club has grown into the largest group of South Asians this side of the Mississippi. We're also the largest student cultural group on campus. Every year we host meetings, community events, free dinners, seasonal snacks, and last but certainly not least, our two flagship cultural shows, each of which attracts over 500 people. These large productions have in the past showcased the best dancing, singing, and acting talent our diverse student community has to offer.

ISABU (Indonesian Students Association at Boston University) is a student-led cultural organization with the purpose of uniting the Indonesian community within the university as well as to promote the Indonesian culture with the community in the Greater Boston Area. Our events set the stage to build a close-knit community for our fellow Indonesian students as well as provide a home-away-from home. We engage in different collaborative projects with other associations within and outside Boston University to provide our members with opportunities to get involved with wider communities and meet new people. The Indonesian Students Association at Boston University serves as a gateway for all students who have an interest in the culture and aesthetic of Indonesia. With our focus on cultivating a developed Indonesian community in Boston University, ISABU aims to connect every individual on campus and provide a valuable and cultural learning experience.

Welcome to INK! Formerly the Illustration Narrative Collaborative, INK is a creative club at BU aimed at artists, writers and storytellers from any medium or background. Whether you're a beginner artist or a wizened industry expert, we have a variety of workshops, critique nights and drawing challenges to help you learn and improve. Come and showcase your talent in our club semester projects or collaborative event! We also host game nights, dinners, art contests, and visit conventions like Anime Boston and MICE. Join us and make friends in BU's art community! :)

Boston University's Inner Strength Gospel Choir (ISGC) is an award-winning, non-denominational, student-run organization devoted to glorifying God through song and praise. Established in 1973, ISGC is a diverse choir comprised of forty-plus members from all walks of life, with different experiences and beliefs. We come together each Sunday evening of the academic year to sing songs of thanks and praise and to support and encourage one another in our daily lives. Each year ISGC hosts three large events: Fall Concert, Spring Concert and our Annual Tour. Fall Concert and Spring Concert are held on campus at Marsh Chapel. For our Annual Tour, we travel to various locations around the country to share our ministry through song and community service and to proudly represent the Boston University Community. We've toured in Dallas, South Carolina, New York, SanFransico, and many other cities around the country. If you are interested in joining ISGC or simply want to learn more about the choir, please attend one of our weekly rehearsals. We are a non-audition choir, so everyone is welcome to join. Rehearsals are held each Sunday evening of the academic year from 7:00 to 9:00pm at Marsh Chapel. We'd love for you to meet us, and for us to meet you!

column1: Interface of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Policy
column4: INSTEP is a new student organization at Boston University that bridges the gap between engineering, science, and public policy. Our mission is to empower students to explore how science and innovation interact with regulation, advocacy, and public impact. Through workshops, case studies, advocacy training, and interdisciplinary collaborations, we aim to create a platform that promotes informed, civic-minded innovation. INSTEP is committed to fostering connections between BU's engineering community??ncluding all disciplines such as mechanical, electrical, computer, systems, and materials??nd broader societal needs.

The InterFraternity Council (IFC) represents all recognized fraternities here at Boston University. As a general assembly comprised of an elected board, chapter presidents, and chapter delegates, the IFC is dedicated to the advancement, safety, and security of each recognized chapter in conjunction with the greater Boston University community. Recognized Fraternities: Alpha Epsilon Pi Chi Phi Kappa Sigma Lambda Chi Alpha Pi Kappa Alpha Phi Kappa Tau Sigma Chi Rush: Recruitment takes place twice a year at the beginning of both the Fall and Spring Semesters. Any men interested in joining Greek Life can find recruitment updates on Instagram @buifc. Case for Fraternity Rights: http://nicindy.org/fraternityrights/

The Boston University International Affairs Association is an academic and professional society focused on bringing a global perspective to the social sciences. We have 5 branches and other committees focused on international affairs: our published undergraduate journal, the International Relations Review; our UNA-USA branch, Students for the UN; Boston University's Model United Nations Team, MUN@BU (ranked 4th in the World!); our collegiate MUN conference BARMUN; and our high school MUN conference BOSMUN! Through these branches, we encourage and promote diplomacy, dialogue, and the understanding of different cultures. As the largest student group on campus and one of the most active, we provide unparalleled opportunities to get involved at BU and beyond. How to Get Involved: Explore our main website at www.buiaa.org, or Instagram @bu_iaa. For more instantaneous updates, join our Slack and sign up for the mailing list to receive weekly newsletters. Come to our open meetings for SUN and MUN@BU (Every Tuesday) and check our website for the time and room that we will be in for the semester! Sign up to staff our conferences at barmun.org and bosmun.org. Of course, you can always email us and ask any question you may have at iaa@bu.edu.

Iota Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated, formally known as the New England Chapter, was the first chapter of any black sorority in the New England Area. Iota chapter was chartered on December 29, 1921, and it is the ninth chapter of the sorority. The sorority's First National President, Sadie T.M. Alexander, and Virginia Alexander came from Grand Chapter in Washington, D.C. to initiate the women who had hopes of becoming members of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc.

Persian Student Association (PSA) is a cultural club focusing on Iranian culture and practices. We are determined to create a community of students who are interested in the Iranian culture whether they come from Iranian descent or not. Our goal is to create a safe space for many international students to feel understood, giving them a space to celebrate and share their culture with their peers. We believe that Boston University is a very diverse university filled with many international students with different backgrounds and we aim to gather all students that are interested in different cultures in our club. We will educate, share and promote our cultural events, creating a close knit community that share similar values.

ISBU strives to aid our members in practicing and becoming educated about their faith, to establish a unifying sense of community and to spread the correct understanding of Islam among students, staff and the greater community, all with the ultimate goal of pleasing Allah (God). Please like our facebook page for updates: https://www.facebook.com/islamicsocietybu Best, ISBU E-Board

The aim of the Italian Students Association, with the mottto "Be Italian, BU", is to foster a strong sense of community between Italians at BU and those members of BU interested in Italian culture. We provide resources through organized events, talks, and meals, but also design a tailored introduction to Boston for incoming students from Italy. The organization aims to create an environment in which the greater Italian community can unite to discuss their views about the culture, current and historic events of Italy. The association will also create a bridge to faculty and alumni, thus stimulating debate and creating a network for Boston University students in Italy. The organization aims to share the Italian culture with students from all around the world and give them access to the Italian way of life through discussions and targeted guest speakers. The group respects the opinions of all members. In order to create an atmosphere in which the group members can share their passions, we will organize dining events and soirees through which the community can share poetry or watch movies in their original language. We will also organize excursions to engage Italian opera pieces and other muscial, literary, culinary, and philosophical resources. Most importantly, through our faculty and alumni we would like to become a regional platform for guest speakers from around the world.

"It's On Us" (to stop sexual assault) is a social movement created by Barack Obama and White House Council on Women and Girls to raise awareness and fight against sexual assault on college campuses for both men and women. It's On Us is a rallying cry inviting everyone to step up and realize that the solution begins with us. It's a declaration that sexual assault is not only a crime committed by a perpetrator against a victim, but a societal problem in which all of us have a role to play. We are reframing sexual assault in a way that inspires everyone to see it as their responsibility to do something, big or small, to prevent it. We are asking everyone involved to create an environment, be it a dorm room, a party, a club or a sports team, or the greater college campus, where sexual assault is unacceptable and survivors are supported. It's On Us chapters establish a team, plan and host events, and conduct educational programs and training such as bystander intervention courses with their peers on campus in order to raise awareness about sexual violence on campus while preventing it from happening in the first place.

JIVA: Jains In Voice and Action is Boston University's Jain student initiative, founded a couple years ago by Jainy Savla, '07 and Purvi Shah '06. JIVA's goals are to increase awareness of the Jain way of life in the university community, promote Jain ideals among the student body, and foster friendships among Jain students. JIVA organizes many educational and interactive activities for its members including guest speakers at BU, temple trips, Jain discussions, celebration of Jain festivals, and frequent social events.

Constantly integrating traditional and modern styles of dance from the East and the West, Jalwa pushes limits with its choreography and fusion elements. Jalwa, or "passion" in Hindi, is what unites this team - a passion to dance, a passion to perform, and a passion to amaze the crowd. Incorporating Hiphop, Bollywood, Bhangra, Classical and Contemporary dance styles, Jalwa has competed on stages nationwide, including competitions in Champaign, Atlanta, Cleveland, Dallas, Minneapolis, and Los Angeles in 2022-23 alone! Our devotion to creativity, overall dedication, and undying love for one another is what sets us apart. We are not just a dance team, we are a family. We are Boston University Jalwa - one team, one passion.

BU Japanese Student Association (BUJSA) is a student-run organization dedicated to promoting greater Japanese awareness and diversity on campus through general meetings and collaborative events with other cultural groups on campus, and other intercollegiate JSAs. We host exciting events throughout the academic year, such as movie and game nights, food outings, and our annual Haunted House, Sushi Formal, and year-end "Omatsuri" Cultural Festival. You can join our events as a general attendee or help plan events as an E-Board member. If you are passionate about Japanese culture and want to contribute to our mission, please consider joining the family!

column1: Jewish on Campus at Boston University
column4: Jewish on Campus (JOC) is the movement of the Jewish future. We seek to revive pride in Judaism by encouraging a new generation of Jews through education, social media campaigning, and grassroots organizing. As a movement powered by students, we seek to end antisemitism on college campuses and beyond. Join our WhatsApp

Kappa Alpha Theta prides itself in fostering the growth of leading women! We value personal excellence, commitment to service, intellectual curiosity, and leadership potential. For our chapter, scholarship is our highest aim, we are proud of our sisters' commitment to this tenent. We also prioritize service to others through our work with Court Appointed Special Advocates, Guardian Ad Litem (CASA GAL). CASA GAL is an organization that pairs trained special advocated with children navigating the court system. These advocated act as both a mentor and voice for the child through this difficult experience. Often, these Advocates are the only person looking after and supporting the child. The work of CASA GAL is deeply important to Kappa Alpha Theta and especially to the Eta Chi chapter at BU. We are proud to support the local Boston CASA chapter and give back to our community. We commit ourselves to hosting events each semester such as Mocktails and Painting and a Theta Dodgeball Tournament, Throw for Theta, to encourage others to get involved, as well as making it fun. The Eta Chi chapter also strongly feels the importance of sisterhood, which we enjoy through movie nights, craft making, ice skating events, and more. Check out our Instagram (@thetabostonu) or contact our VP Administration (buthetacao@gmail.com), to find out more about our wonderful community of leading women!

The Eta Phi chapter of Kappa Delta came to BU in 2010. We are a diverse group of women with strong leadership skills and an enthusiastic presence on campus. Kappa Delta organizes and holds many philanthropy, sisterhood, and social events throughout the year. Kappa Delta was founded at State Female Normal School (now Longwood University) in 1897 formed for the purpose of promoting confidence and encouraging women to be their best selves through the power of friendship. Kappa Delta makes great things happen in women. If you would like to contact this student group, please reach out to our President at president.bukappadelta@gmail.com.
The Theta Beta Chapter of Kappa Kappa Psi at Boston University is a gender inclusive service fraternity dedicated to the improvement of the Boston University Bands.

Since established at the University of Virginia on December 10 1869, Kappa Sigma Fraternity has initiated more members than any other fraternal organization in the country. The Mu Psi Chapter of the Kappa Sigma Fraternity was founded at Boston University on November 14th, 1987. We are a values-based men's fraternity guided by the four pillars of Fellowship, Leadership, Scholarship, and Service. We are currently the largest, most diverse fraternity on campus. We pride ourselves on our various philanthropic efforts across campus and the greater Boston area. With brotherhood at the core of everything we do, our organization cultivates connections and life-long friendships for college and beyond.

Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc. is a historical Black Greek-letter fraternity founded on the campus of Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana on January 5th 1911. It was founded by 10 astute men with the fundamental purpose of the fraternity being "honorable achievement in every field of human endeavor. Chi Chapter was chartered on the Boston University campus on February 15, 1924, by the significant six: Maceo Hubbard, Julian Evans, Courtney Cooley, Theodore Nathaniel D. Scott, J. Logan Jenkins, and John Hunter. Chi Chapter is the 22nd undergraduate chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc. and the fifth undergraduate charter to be awarded in the then-Eastern Province (now Northeastern Province).

Pickup soccer? Casual games? Watch Parties? This is the club for you! PS: Check out our instagram kasualkicksbu for more information! The players behind Kasual Kicks believe that soccer is more than just a game; we believe it's a way to connect, learn, and grow. Through our events, such as recreational games, watch parties, twilight soccer games, and more, we strive to cultivate a community of soccer enthusiasts of ALL skill levels where they can engage in the sport they love, share their passion for soccer, and foster growth through teamwork and friendly competition. Kasual Kicks is DEDICATED to creating a welcoming environment for players from beginner to advanced. Our mission is to create a community where soccer serves as a bridge for people to meet and get to know eachtoehr through their common love of soccer. This focus on recreational play rather than intense competition offers a balanced and enjoyable experience for students looking to stay active, have fun and meet people.

Welcome to Qazaq Student Association at Boston University! We're a vibrant and inclusive organization dedicated to promoting awareness and fostering appreciation of the Kazakhstani community nestled within the bustling city of Boston. Our mission is to cultivate a rich tapestry of cultural exchange, education, and social engagement, creating a warm and inviting space where individuals from all walks of life can come together to celebrate diversity and strengthen community bonds. We believe in the power of meaningful connections and the transformative potential of cross-cultural exchange. Through a diverse array of intellectual, cultural, and social events, we strive to provide a platform for dialogue, learning, and celebration. Whether you're interested in exploring the rich history and traditions of Kazakhstan, engaging in thought-provoking discussions on contemporary issues, or simply connecting with fellow members of the community, there's something for everyone at QSABU. From educational seminars and workshops to vibrant cultural festivals and holiday celebrations, our calendar is filled with opportunities for growth, connection, and celebration. We also organize conferences and special events tailored to the unique needs and interests of students and families from Kazakhstan, providing valuable resources and support to help them thrive in their new home away from home. Above all, QSABU is committed to creating a safe and inclusive space where individuals of all backgrounds feel welcome, valued, and respected. We believe that by coming together with open hearts and minds, we can bridge divides and build a stronger, more cohesive community for all. Join us as we on this enriching journey of discovery, connection, and celebration. Together, let's make a difference and build a brighter future for the Kazakhstani community in Boston and beyond

Kesem is a nationwide community, driven by passionate college student leaders, that supports children through and beyond their parent's cancer. A program of Kesem, Camp Kesem operates free summer camps for children who have been impacted by a parent's cancer. Kesem's mission of supporting children through and beyond a parent's cancer, and our vision of ensuring that every child impacted by a parent's cancer is never alone, can only be realized through an ongoing, steadfast commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in every part of our organization. Camp Kesem at Boston University was founded in 2017 and held their first camp in August 2018. As of 2020, we support over 50 campers.

The Boston University Korean Graduate Student Association (BU KGSA) is a dedicated student organization aimed at supporting and uniting Korean graduate students at Boston University. Our mission is to create a strong sense of community among Korean graduate students through cultural, academic, and social events that enhance their university experience. BU KGSA is committed to enriching the cultural diversity of the campus, promoting academic collaboration, and providing a platform for personal and professional development.

column1: Khmer Student Association at Boston University
column4: The Khmer Student Association at Boston University is dedicated to fostering a vibrant community of Khmer students on campus. It serves as a welcoming space for individuals to explore and engage with Khmer culture, providing opportunities for Khmer Americans to reconnect with their heritage and offering a supportive environment for international students from Cambodia. The association advocates for community and unity, reflecting this through cultural, educational, and social events. Membership is open to all BU students who have an interest in Khmer culture and related studies. The club hosts general body meetings at least once a month, coordinated by the President, along with regular executive board meetings to ensure smooth operation and planning of events. The organization is committed to inclusivity, with no membership fees and a policy against discrimination of any kind. The executive board oversees the club's activities and initiatives, aiming to cultivate a strong Khmer community within Boston University and beyond.

column1: Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program
column4: The Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program (KDSAP) is a student-run organization that provides free kidney health screenings and health education to underserved communities in Boston and in the Greater Boston Area. We provide programs geared towards improving the health of underserved populations. According to the National Kidney Foundation, 1 in 3 American adults is currently at risk for developing chronic kidney disease. What's worse is that 1 in 9 American adults already have kidney disease and don't know it yet. KDSAP aims to raise awareness about chronic kidney disease and help prevent its onset by providing free kidney screenings to underserved communities. There are multiple components to this program, including community health screenings, community health education events, and opportunities to participate in colloquia on and off campus. KDSAP was founded in 2008 by students at Harvard University under the direction of Dr. Li-Li Hsiao. There are currently 20 chapters of KDSAP in the Unites States and Canada.

This club is for those interested in the fiber arts particularly knitting and crochet. BU Knitting club meets every Thursday from 7-8:30 pm (location TBA)! Whether you knit or crochet, are a newbie or expert, feel free to stop by! If you're interested in joining us please use the link below to join the mailing list, just joining the group on Terrier Central won't automatically sign you up for it! The link below leads to our mailing list signup, if you put in your email we'll be able to keep you informed about how and when we'll be meeting, along with other important information http://eepurl.com/dL0Cok

Korean Communication Association (KOMMA) works to provide information and networks to its members and all Koreans at Boston University through mass media projects. While its previous projects focused on unilateral communication like magazine, radio, or Instagram trivia, KOMMA began its video projects in Fall 2022. While self-PR through online platforms- both for a company and individual- is crucial for its success, KOMMA's mission is to educate and assist the members in effectively improving their social media skills, focusing on YouTube and Instagram. The use of various media platforms allows students to learn about content-creating programs, gain experience in the field, and build connections.

The Boston University Korean Student Association (buKSA) is an evolving yet dedicated student organization devoted to serving and educating the community of the Korean American heritage through cultural, informative, and social events. buKSA also strives to raise awareness in Korean-related current events, raise funding for related supporting charities, and participate in spreading the current rise of the Hallyu wave. The club creates networking opportunities with intercollegiate cultural groups and aims to foster a community in which students may find a sense of identity and purpose.

Kappa Theta Pi is the nation's first technology-based professional fraternity, accepting students from all majors. KTP has five pillars: professional development, alumni connections, social growth, technological advancement, and academic support.

Lambda Chi Alpha at Boston University is a fraternity committed to fostering leadership, academic excellence, and a strong sense of brotherhood. Our members engage in various philanthropic efforts, campus activities, and social events, creating a well-rounded and supportive community. We pride ourselves on upholding the values of loyalty, duty, respect, and service, providing an enriching college experience that extends beyond graduation. Join us to be part of a brotherhood that empowers you to grow and succeed.

LatinasBU is a student-led organization at Boston University dedicated to empowering, supporting, and celebrating Latina and femme-identifying students. Our mission is to create a safe and affirming community where members can connect through shared cultural experiences, personal growth, and leadership development. Through social events, cultural programming, workshops, mentorship, and advocacy initiatives, LatinasBU fosters a strong sisterhood rooted in identity, empowerment, and community. We aim to uplift Latina voices on campus, build meaningful relationships, and inspire future Latina leaders within and beyond Boston University.

A non-religious and non-political organization that aims to share the Lebanese culture with the students at Boston University and larger Boston community through cultural events and gatherings. People of all nationalities are welcome to all our events.

Let's Talk About It aims to promote self-care and mindfulness by creating a safe space for both formal and informal conversations about mental health. Members will check in on each others' daily lives and promote everyday acts of kindness for ourselves and others. We will provide healthy coping strategies for those struggling with stress, anxiety, and other difficulties. We plan to host workshops and discussions centered around wellness, while also being a social club where students can come to chat and relax. Our target audience is any BU student seeking to work on their mental health and self-growth in a non-judgemental space with other like-minded people. We are committed to providing a diverse, inclusive environment with students from all different backgrounds who can all offer their unique perspectives towards mental health. We hope to provide students with a foundation in mindfulness that they will be able to build upon throughout their life while also allowing for opportunities to lower and handle the current stresses that come with being in college. The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the mental health struggles our generation faces, which inspired us to create a club that prepares people to cope with stress during the pandemic but also in the long term. Many don't realize the impact of mindfulness until they are faced with mental health crises. One of our goals is to stop the problem before it begins. By encouraging students to practice self-care regularly, we hope that it will keep them in a healthy mindset and provide them with strategies for when problems arise. Self-care is often overlooked as many students prioritize their studies or social lives over their wellbeing. Recently, there have been attempts to improve students' mental health through occasional wellness events and discussions hosted by the BU administration or clubs that are related to the topic of wellness. However, Let's Talk About It will provide an ongoing space for students to have a stigma-free community to learn mindfulness techniques and coping skills by promoting the importance of self-care at Boston University. We will also encourage and host challenges promoting everyday acts of kindness in the BU Community. Everyone in the club will have a say on what kind of workshops we hold or discussions we host. Members will have access to an anonymous form where they may express what they are presently struggling with and submit their suggestions to the E-Board. Our platform will be easily accessible and provide a broad range of topics based on the members' most relevant wants and needs. Meetings will occur every other week on a set day and time and workshops will be held on the “off weeks” without a set day or time. We will focus on specific mental health topics during meetings that give members direct mechanisms to handle their stress. These discussions will be hosted by guest speakers who will lead the members through an open discussion about the topic of interest. Each meeting will start with breathing exercises so we can all enter a more relaxed state of mind. We will then progress into a presentation that starts the conversation and explains the topic of interest for the evening. We will break off into small groups to check in with each other and then express our ideas about the topic. After the conversation, there will be a small meditation to re-center everyone, as many of these discussions can be difficult to have. During workshops, we plan on teaching members how to knit, about the use of crystals, the benefits of meditation/yoga, and other self-care and wellness-related activities. In these workshops, there will be a designated leader that will guide the members through the planned activity (sometimes there will be a few leaders, e.g. learning crocheting requires hands-on help and therefore more helpers). At the end of the workshop, we will have an open discussion about the activity and how it helps to cope with stress. We also plan to raise money through fundraisers (such as selling merchandise, bake sales, social media challenges, etc.) to donate to different mental health organizations. Members will vote to decide where the donation will be going. These fundraisers will occasionally be in collaboration with other clubs and organizations at BU. At the beginning of the fall semester, we will start with more laid-back conversations about mental health when the club is just getting started so the members can get to know each other a little better first before diving into difficult conversations. It's possible that members may feel uncomfortable at first so we'll ease this tension by facilitating bonding exercises and mental health check-ins while asking for suggestions about what members would like to discuss later in the semester. We will then take these suggestions into account and start our schedule of discussions once every other week with wellness events and workshops on the “off weeks.” A general schedule of wellness events will be determined before the start of each semester so that the appropriate funding may be allocated. We believe these are realistic goals because we already have connections within the BU community and beyond. We already have guest speakers lined up for the fall semester who have agreed to lead discussions on LGBTQIA+ mental health, eating disorders, body image, sexual health, and other related topics. These include other clubs at BU such as Active Minds BU, professors at BU such as Sarah Gilbert, or doctors such as Dr. Sara Haverty. There are 40 members on our mailing list and over 110 followers on our Instagram page. Furthermore, we have already hosted a general interest meeting, where students expressed their need for a club like ours on campus. During the summer, we plan to continue to grow our social media following and reach out to more potential guest speakers and clubs to collaborate with while preparing presentations and tentative schedules for the fall semester. Though current clubs have wellness activities planned, there is no student group focused specifically on self-care and practicing mindfulness within a close-knit community. Our club will be an accessible and highly useful resource for students struggling with their mental health.

Love language? So do we.The Boston University Linguistics Association is where syntax meets snacks and semantics sparks friendships. Whether you're fluent in IPA or just curious about how words work, we host events that mix mind-expanding talks with good vibes. Hop into our Discord to chat, learn, and linguist with us: https://discord.gg/CvZAF9tfEb

Liquid Fun is Boston University's short and long form improv comedy troupe. Since our unofficial founding in 1998, we have gone on to win countless tournaments and awards including the 2018-2019 New England Regional College Improve Championship! We perform free shows each month on BU's campus. But we don't stop there. We have performed at nearly every college in Massachusetts, Bar/Bat Mitzvahs, comedy theaters, fundraisers and more. Every year we host a 24-hour comedy marathon to raise money for the Great Boston Area Food Bank. "Audition" is not a part of the LF vocabulary. We hold open practices, year-round, on Sunday nights from 7-9 PM in BU College of Arts and Sciences B36. No experience necessary! Our open practices include teaching and performing improv. Variety is our middle name despite what you may have heard (“Felix” is just a vicious rumor ). It's free. It's fun... it's liquid?
