The Mathematics Association at BU aims to create a close-knit community among all students interested in mathematics, statistics, and mathematical sciences. MABU dedicated to mathematics accessible at the undergraduate level. MABU aspires to offer a variety of academic, professional, and social events catering to the interests of BU undergraduate mathematics & statistics community.

We hope to create a space where students can play, discuss, and partake in the culture of Mahjong, the most popular game in Asia, in a recreational and competitive setting. We will achieve this by having students play Mahjong during club meetings and by holding tournament events for more competitive players. We will also host teaching programs for players of all skill levels and have community events revolving around Mahjong.

Malaysian Cultural Association has a two-pronged approach with community outreach, which is to act as a support system for Malaysian students at Boston University and to introduce and teach about Malaysian culture to the student community.

The Boston University Marine Science Association is a student group committed to learning about different marine science related topics by going on field trips, attending lectures, and exchanging information about personal experiences with marine-related jobs and internships. All who are interested in the ocean and its inhabitants are welcome. Follow us on Instagram: @msaatbu

The BU Medical Ethics Society is an organization for undergraduates who express interest in the healthcare field. Together we explore the ethics behind science, research, and policies of healthcare. The Society aims to educate young adults beyond the classroom through peer discussion, guest speakers, and much more!

The Mexican Students Association at Boston University is dedicated to celebrating and preserving Mexican culture, identity, and community on campus. Our mission is to create a welcoming and empowering space for students of Mexican heritage—and anyone interested in our culture—to connect, share experiences, and feel at home, even while far from home. Through cultural events, community-building initiatives, and collaborative efforts with other student groups, we aim to promote pride in our roots and strengthen the visibility of the Mexican and Latino presence at BU.

Our goal as a club is to educate the Boston University community about the positive impact that micro-finance has in pushing for positive educational, political, and social change in the developing world. Members will apply their learnings to conduct research about developing countries and entrepreneurial ecosystems to make truly impactful investment decisions. Members will gain real world micro-finance experience while getting the opportunity to apply knowledge acquired in classes and club meetings. Cross disciplinary collaboration is an integral part of our club, as our organization is open to all undergraduate students in the hope that we can come together and share our diverse experiences and backgrounds to push for positive change.

Increasing polarization on migration is a pressing issue of our globalized world; however, real migrant experience lacks media representation. So our mission is to create a story-sharing platform for migration narratives. Leveraging the power of storytelling, we hope to debunk migration myths and celebrate diversity, inclusivity, and empathy by publishing stories and research. We aim to provide an accessible platform where people of all ages and educational backgrounds can learn more about migration, acquiring knowledge that was exclusively circulated among scholars and policymakers. Our team consists of writers, researchers, podcasters, and community outreach members.

The Mind and Brain Society (MBS) aims to support an eager undergraduate community with conversations and resources that are fundamental to Neuroscience and Psychology today. Throughout the academic year, MBS hosts lectures, research presentations, educational outreach programs, and social events. The MBS divisions — the Nerve and Synaptic Connection — give members the opportunity to publish their own works, receive mentorship from upperclassmen in the Neuroscience, Neurobiology, and Psychology departments, and gain peer-mentorship experience. More information about our initiatives can be found on our website!

The mission of the Minority Association of Pre-Medical/Health Students (MAPS) is to address the needs of the minority Pre-Health students at Boston University. MAPS intends to motivate, encourage, and prepare Pre-Health students from a disadvantaged background, an underrepresented minority group, or a medically underserved area to be competitive applicants for health professional schools through a sharing of knowledge, experience, and mentorship. The chapter is dedicated to serving underserved communities through community service activities and volunteering and to improving minority matriculation into all professional health-related programs.

The word "miXx" is a stylized version of the word "mix," where we aim to mix together people of different cultures and backgrounds to create one group filled with people who love and appreciate K-Pop. The large "X" stands for "cross-cultural communication," as we aim to learn more about and enjoy a part of Korean culture through K-Pop and dance. We were founded by two Boston University alums. We are currently active in both Japan and Boston. Those who are interested in K-Pop or who would like to learn more about it, those with dance experience or those without, those who like singing or would like to start, or those who are interested in learning more about Korean culture are strongly encouraged to join! With the system we have established, our club accommodates those with busy schedules, as you can make this club's time commitment as intense or as lax as you would like according to what you can manage. We look forward to your participation in our club!

Mediation is a unique, internationally-growing legal field that seeks to facilitate meaningful discussion and encourage collaborative resolution through the use of a neutral third-party. Whether you are an aspiring attorney or simply looking to try a new extracurricular activity, as a member, you will experience how the skill of mediation is rewarding and widely-applicable. Boston University's Mock Mediation team is dedicated to excellence and is highly regarded across the country. Every year, the Mock Mediation team is recognized as one of the top four in the country, and members receive both team and individual awards.

The Boston University Mock Trial Organization is a student-run organization focused on competing in mock trial at the collegiate level. This encompasses acting as attorney and witnesses to (fictionally) try both criminal and civil court cases in front of actual attorneys. We are a member of the American Mock Trial Association and have a long history of competing at invitational, regional, and national tournaments.

Mu Epsilon Delta is Boston University's first and only nationally affiliated pre-health fraternity. Our mission is to create an inclusive, supportive, and multidisciplinary space where students pursuing any pre-health path, medicine, dentistry, veterinary, PA, public health, and more, can thrive together. Unlike other pre-health organizations on campus, Mu Epsilon Delta is built on the foundation of brotherhood, offering Bigs and Littles, family lines, and a close-knit network that supports academic, emotional, and professional growth. We are open to all students regardless of GPA, academic standing, or specific career goals. Whether you're pre-med, pre-dental, or still figuring it out, you'll find a home with us. Through weekly meetings, bonding events, hands-on clinics (like suturing and CPR certification), guest speakers, and service projects, we prepare our members not only for professional school, but for a life of purpose and connection in healthcare. Our national affiliation allows us to provide access to an extended network of students, alumni, and practicing professionals. We've already hosted events with speakers like Dr. Anthony Schena (Boston Celtics team physician), and our members have gained internships, shadowing, and job opportunities through fraternity connections. We also uplift first-generation and underrepresented students by providing accessible resources like shared MCAT prep materials, EMS job support, and peer mentoring. Joining Mu Epsilon Delta means gaining a family of future healthcare professionals who study together, grow together, and push each other to succeed. We're not just preparing for careers, we're building lifelong friendships and a stronger, more inclusive healthcare community.

The Boston University Music Business Club aims to foster a vibrant community of student musicians and those interested in exploring the music industry in any way. Students will be able to apply to become 'student artists' and will be assigned teams consisting of MBC members. Students on artist teams will learn how to manage artists, develop marketing tactics and materials, and create social content for their artists. MBC hosts events such as artist showcases, networking events with industry professionals, and other group bonding events.

Matthew 17:20 says that faith as small as a mustard seed can move mountains. As a collegiate a cappella group, we strive to touch and move mountains in people's hearts. We hope to entertain and inspire our audiences at BU and in the local Boston area through our stories and songs.

BU Flag Football has been going on for a whole year now. Twice a week, we all meet to play flag football or 7v7 amongst ourselves. BU hasn't previously offered a football related club, so it would be a good addition to the extracurriculars of the school. The club is also a community where we have been doing fun things together such as watching games. We've welcomed new people, and the club has been a great place to make new friends with common interests and play a fun popular sport recreationally while improving together.

The North African Student Organization (NASO) at Boston University is a club open to all full-time undergraduate and graduate students – mainly supporting and empowering the North African community. The organization's aim and purpose is serving as a hub for all North African scholars to connect and form meaningful connections with one another. Moreover, NASO will also serve as an opportunity for cultural rooting and awareness – for those willing to learn more about MENA culture.

The National Society of Black Engineers aims to maintain the mission "to increase the number of culturally responsible Black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community." We are a chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE) but we accept any member who cares to support our cause or who feels that they may benefit from our efforts. We aim to serve as active members in our university, our community, and in NSBE through events, community service, and attendance of NSBE conferences.

column1: National Student Speech Language Hearing Association
column4: NSSLHA (we pronounce it "NISS-LA") is the student branch of the American Speech Language and Hearing Association (ASHA). To join the national organization, email Doctor Jennifer Bentley at bentley1@bu.edu and she will forward your information to the e-board! All undergraduate students interested in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology are encouraged to play an active role in the BU NSSLHA chapter by attending meetings and volunteering for fundraising and other activities. Speech Language and Hearing Sciences minors and other students interested in the field are welcome.

The Navigators at Boston University is a community of students and friends who want to know God and Jesus Christ, and who want to love and encourage each other while walking through life together in Boston. There are no prerequisites or specific affiliations required to participate in Navigators activities. We encourage you to come just as you are and enjoy friendship and community with us as we seek to understand who God is and why it matters.

Every three minutes, someone is diagnosed with a life-threatening blood disease such as leukemia. For thousands of these patients, a blood stem cell transplant is their best—or only—hope. However, 70% of patients in need of a transplant do not have a fully matched donor in their family. As a result, patients turn to NMDP (formally known as Be The Match), the non-profit organization that operates the world's largest and most diverse registry of potential blood stem cell donors. The more registry members, the greater the likelihood that patients will find their lifesaving donor. All it takes to join the registry is a swab! NMDP is a student-run organization that partners with the national NMDP organization to offer hope to individuals with blood diseases or blood cancers. We seek to increase and diversify the NMDP registry and increase awareness about the importance of cellular therapy. NMDP Campus Chapters was established by the national nonprofit organization NMDP, operated by the National Marrow Donor Program. There are currently over 100 NMDP groups at universities and colleges across the nation with the goal of expanding NMDP's lifesaving mission—delivering cures for blood diseases. Save lives with us!

The BU Undergraduate Sociology Association (BUUSA) strives to engage Sociology majors/minors and the BU undergraduate community on the themes, concepts, and skills central to the discipline of Sociology. Members of BUUSA are invested in contemplating sociological issues while applying differing sociological perspectives to the social world. Events and meetings sponsored by the BUUSA are meant to unify and engage students who are interested in sociology. BUUSA's mission is to enhance undergraduate students' understanding of the discipline, engage Sociology majors/minors, and encourage stronger relationships with Sociology faculty.

The BU Nutrition & Dietetics Club (BUNDC) offers a balanced mix of academic and social activities centered around nutrition, health, and wellness. Our academic events—like guest lectures, professor coffee chats, and interactive educational games—are great ways to deepen your knowledge, build connections, and grow beyond the classroom. On the social side, we host group cooking and baking nights where members come together to create and enjoy tasty, nutritious recipes. We also organize fun outings like farmers market trips, which are always a hit! Interested in joining us? Reach out to us at bunutritionclub@gmail.com—we'd love to have you!

Off The Cuff is Boston University's only award-winning fashion, arts, and culture publication. During the year, we do photoshoots and magazines that train creatives in fashion, makeup, photography, art direction, etc.

Our community service initiative meets weekly to crochet hand warmers and winter gear to donate to homeless groups within Boston through the community service centre. It is an excellent way to get community service hours in while learning a new transformative skill with mental and physical benefits.

OHA-BU is an organization dedicated to spreading awareness about the importance of oral health to the BU community and the local Boston area. At meetings we learn about the prevention of oral related diseases and treatments taught by dental professionals. Our group also partakes in various community service events, as well as fundraises money and oral hygiene products to donate to local charities. OHA-BU is open to all undergraduate BU students that want to create a more equitable society, both locally and globally.

Omega Phi Alpha, Boston University's only community service sorority, is focused on our principles of friendship, leadership, and service. Our service is dedicated to the university community, the community at large, the members of the sorority, and the nations of the world. We also complete service every year in dedication to our permanent project of mental health. Through the completion of service, the sisters of Omega Phi Alpha hope to become service-minded leaders that have the confidence, drive, and the perspective to change the world.

Boston University On Broadway (OB) is BU's premiere musical theatre organization, dedicated to bringing quality musical productions and theater-related events to the Boston University community. Founded in 1994, OB has become a fixture of artistic life on campus, putting on a variety of shows that have ranged from Broadway classics to the edgy and the avant-garde. We pride ourselves in being a group that teaches our members to be involved with whatever aspect of a production the choose. There are opportunities for actors, singers, dancers, directors, music directors, choreographers, producers, and any technical role you can think of. Please visit our website to learn more about us! http://bostonuniversityonbroadway.com/

BU's only tap dancing group! We are a small group of passionate tap dancers that bring talent from all over to form this close community. We are a student run, student choreographed performing group that rehearses twice a week. We perform in numerous dance shows on campus, as well as our annual showcase at the end of the year.

One Voice is Boston University's multicultural, multi-genre a cappella group, originally founded as Kol Echad in 1995. As their name implies, they aim to deliver a musical experience that embraces a mix of styles and cultures within the ever-popular collegiate a cappella sound. The group is a mainstay throughout the Northeast and often sings at cultural centers and universities, including Harvard, Brandeis, Rutgers, and Tufts.
