The club was founded in the fall of 2002 with the hopes of rekindling the spirit of celebrating all that is Pakistan begun by the Pakistani students associations of the past. Students of Pakistani heritage have been an active part of the Boston University community for decades, and it is the goal of the OPS to continue their strive to establish a clear portrayal of Pakistan and its culture and to be part of the multi-ethnic fabric of BU and the city of Boston. So join us in showing your Pakistani Pride and demonstrating how great Pakistan is! Pakistan Zindabad!

The Outing Club strives to bring the joy of the great outdoors to the BU community. From urban explorations to trekking the White Mountains, we're 100% driven by the desire to take adventures beyond the BU campus. Our mission? To promote an appreciation for the natural environment through outdoor recreation. But we also just love to have fun. Check out linktr.ee/buoutingclub to follow us on instagram, and join our email list where we send weekly emails about our upcoming trips and make sure to come to weekly meetings where we will go over previous and upcoming trips as well as a weekly event that can range from structure building in the wild to planning meals on long backpacking trips. Our first meeting is on Monday 9/8/2025 at 8:15p in COM 101 All other meetings are Mondays at 8p in SCI 109
The OEC oversees all 12 individual Residence Hall Associations on campus to facilitate community engagement, participation and initiating greater conversation across Residence Life.

With 650 established Pre-Law, Law, and Alumni Chapters in the U.S. and 330,000 members internationally, Phi Alpha Delta is the largest co-ed professional law fraternity in the country, and it is the first law fraternity to have an open membership where any student in good standing at an institution can join and utilize our resources. As the world's largest legal organization, Phi Alpha Delta is able to offer a variety of unique member benefits such as: Membership that can transition with you from college to law school and beyond. Senior Transition program which connects pre-law graduates to their new law school chapters. An expansive worldwide network that includes U.S. Presidents, Supreme Court Justices, Cabinet Members, Senators, Governors, and prominent attorneys. National Mock Trial Competition The Society of Scholars LSAT Prep discounts National leadership training events, such as the annual Pre-Law Conference and Leadership Summit.

The Boston University Panhellenic Council is the governing body for the ten sororities chartered on campus. Panhel, with the help of one delegate from each sorority, helps to regulate Greek Life and maintain its growth on campus. We work to provide each member of an affiliated chapter with an opportunity for leadership, scholarship, university involvement, networking and support, and friendship. Recognized sororities: - Alpha Delta Pi (ADPi) - Alpha Epsilon Phi (AEPhi) - Alpha Phi (APhi) - Delta Delta Delta (TriDelt) - Delta Gamma (DG) - Gamma Phi Beta (GPhiB) - Kappa Alpha Theta (Theta) - Kappa Delta (KD) - Sigma Delta Tau (SigDelt) - Sigma Kappa (SK)

Welcome to PERIOD. at BU, a youth-fueled nonprofit that strives to eradicate period poverty and stigma through service, education, and advocacy. Fall 2025 Interest Form/Mailing List: https://forms.gle/TapuDjLmBPh14cYn9 What We Do: Service, Education, and Advocacy Education & Discussion - Education & discussion on various topics (period stigma, sustainable menstruation, abortion access, reproductive disorders, etc) Fundraiser & Donations - Period poverty fundraiser - Menstrual product drive - Product & financial donation to local shelters Outreach & Advocacy - Education outreach for local youth - "How much does BU know?" video project - Reproductive rights legislation advocacy Fun PERIOD. Activities - Reproductive rights jeopardy - Paint and sip arts and crafts - Movie & snacks night ... and many more!??Learn more about us at www.periodatbu.com and www.instagram.com/periodatbu. https://youtu.be/pgYNBzZgBFI?feature=shared

Phi Chi Theta Zeta Chapter is a professional co-ed business fraternity for all majors and minors at Boston University. Originally established in the 1920s, the Zeta chapter was one of the eight original founding national chapters of Phi Chi Theta. Unlike other professional organizations on campus, our mission centers on social and digital entrepreneurship, providing the professional and social resources needed to navigate the startup world. Like a startup, we do not limit ourselves to business-minded individuals. Our commitment to academic and professional diversity is evident amongst our organization. We currently boast ten separate majors across five colleges: Questrom, CAS, COM, SAR, and ENG. We also differentiate ourselves via our focus on utilizing management and business as a channel for fostering positive social change. Our organization's emphasis on technology and ethical leadership parallels the Questrom School of Business' newly revised curriculum, implemented in 2013.

Welcome to PPE! This is a space for students of all ideological affiliations to come and freely express their opinions on any topics concerning Politics, Philosophy, and Economics. We seek to foster good-faith discussion, ensuring that everyone is able to state their views and opinions without being yelled over. If you're interested in any of the aforementioned fields or just want a group of people to talk and/or listen to, please feel free to stop by a meeting and join in. We're always happy to have new ideas in any form.

The laws of physics govern everything in the universe, from the most distant stars and galaxies to our own bodies and brains. Learning about physics is one of the best ways to learn more about the world we live in and how it works, no matter your background in science or math. In Photon, we learn more about the physical world through activities and demonstrations, faculty talks, career building events, and field trips to local museums and laboratories. Most of all, we have fun exploring the laws of nature and learning about the universe. You do not have to be a physics major to join, as the diversity of our group is one of our greatest strengths.

PHPC is an independently run organization, focused on building a community from scratch. Our goals are to create a supportive, stress-free environment while building our network and gaining valuable insight into different pre-health fields. As a group our primary goal is to contribute philanthropically and through community service, dedicating our lives to the service of others. This organization upholds the standards of academic excellence, professionalism, and integrity in all endeavors.

BUPTA is an organization that consists of all students involved in the Doctor of Physical Therapy program here at Boston University. We organize social events for the PT students, get involved in the local community, and raise money for the nationwide Marquette Challenge which funds physical therapy research and is sponsored by the Foundation for Physical Therapy. We strive to keep our members in touch with ways to better themselves and their future careers in the area of physical therapy by providing educational seminars and opportunities.

The Lambda Nu Chapter was colonized in late November of 2004. The group was made up of a diverse group of approximately 30 men with a lofty set of goals to meet in order to be chartered. Over the next year and a half, the colony, under the leadership of President Chase Classen, grew in both size and scope. The chapter was chartered on April 8th, 2006 with 63 brothers. Since receving our charter in the Spring of 2006, the Lambda Nu Chapter has gone on to be recognized as a fraternity at Boston University. We involve ourselves in multiple arenas, inlcuding athletics, philanthropy, community service, and social. Some of our more noted achievements in the past year include approximately 2000 hours of community service and nearly $38,000 raised for charity. In each of our first three years of existence, we won the Fraternity of the Year Award at Boston University. We hope to earn back this tittle by the end of this school year. History of the Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity The Pi Kappa Alpha International Fraternity is a Greek letter, secret, college, social fraternity. It was founded at the University of Virginia on March 1, 1868. The Fraternity is composed of men who share similar ideals of friendship, truth, honor, and loyalty. The Fraternity's ideals are expressed in the written words and symbols of a secret ritual. These ideals and members' ability to maintain the visions of the Fraternity's founders are the great moral legacy of Pi Kappa Alpha. More information on the fraternity can be found at www.pikes.org.

Pioneer Impact Consulting provides students a chance to consult on projects with a variety of businesses for social impact - providing skill support and powerful insights into various dimensions of the client's businesses, while gaining experience to help entrepreneurs grow and develop their businesses. Organization will connect with clients from a variety of businesses (including original focus area of ambitious refugees and immigrants) to develop their business ideas with the help of student members to work as consultants, providing skill support and powerful insights into various dimensions of the client's businesses. PIC Club will provide students with the opportunity to work with these clients and help them strengthen their business and consulting skills. Through the organization, students will have the opportunity to engage with diverse perspectives, gain real-world entrepreneurial experience, and contribute to the growth of businesses. The purpose of the club is to train students in the fields of consulting, strategy, and business development, providing key insights into how real businesses work by connecting them with clients. The E-Board will connect and oversee the members to ensure effective coordination and efficient assistance. This oversight includes monitoring resource allocation, evaluating program effectiveness, and maintaining communication channels to address any emerging needs or challenges promptly. The goal is to optimize impact and uphold accountability in serving our clients and community stakeholders.

The Pinky Toe is a multimedia, intersectional-feminist satire publication that regularly and consistently produces content for and about the Boston University community. The Pinky Toe aims to amplify the voices of those who identify as part of the LGBTQ+ and/or BIPOC community to provide a reliable outlet for students at a challenging university in a fast-paced city to smile, laugh and know that other students are going through similar struggles and experiences. In achieving this mission, The Pinky Toe actively seeks out and initiates collaboration between Boston University students across a wide range of interests including but not limited to writing, editing, web design, photography, social media, filmmaking, computer science, management and all forms of comedy. The Pinky Toe provides opportunities for students to understand the inner workings of a multimedia publication, learn and practice a wide variety of types of satire, participate in the editing and revising of their contributions and gain active leadership and management experience on a large, hardworking staff. The Pinky Toe aims to seek out new, creative ideas to determine the best ways to encourage dialogue about pop culture, politics, and current events.

The Zeta Pi chapter at Boston University began when two men, inspired by the vision of Phi Kappa Tau chapters across the country, set out to create their own chapter and a new fraternal experience beginning with the core values of distinguished leadership and the creation of men of distinction. Since the fall of 2016, when this all took place, the Zeta Pi chapter has flourished and subsequently expanded its mission. While holding true to the values of the national organization, the Zeta Pi chapter works to define what it means to be a fraternity man. While these experiences alone help develop leadership skills, our true goal is to promote ethical leadership in both our chapter and our community. In the brotherhood, our resident council is comprised of men from many different nationalities, backgrounds, and experiences. Phi Tau's style of government ensures the opinions, ideas, and views of all our brothers are thoughtfully and meaningfully considered. The democratic nature of our leadership structure lends fluidly to the inclusion of many sentiments and perspectives. Outside of the chapter, ethical leadership means taking on relevant and impactful problems. Since our founding, our brothers have worked diligently against sexual assault in our community. Rather than taking a passive stance, our brothers have addressed the issue head-on by leading sexual assault awareness and education groups such as BU's 16K Strong. This involvement keeps our members and other BU students informed, aware, and empowered to make change. In addition to this involvement, the Zeta Pi chapter also weaves ethical leadership into community service by confronting another large issue: climate change. Our numerous events, which have included cleaning up the Charles River and services for Boston's National Audubon Society, share an emphasis on ecological conservation. Our brotherhood has embraced the opportunity to model the way to a cleaner and more environmentally responsible future. Each semester, our chapter donates over $2500 to SeriousFun, a non-profit that offers camps to children with terminal or debilitating illnesses. To raise this money, our chapter created The Garden, a venue where Berklee bands and Allston bands can perform and collect donations for SeriousFun. The Garden allows us to raise money for our philanthropy while also creating valuable ties with other individuals and organizations outside of BU.

Imagine turning your tech ideas into a reality, all without ever touching a line of code. That's what product management is all about.Learn about business and the process of software development and own your own product at PMReady.PMReady hosts weekly developmental workshops and speaker events to provide experience to aspiring Product Managers (PM). PMReady's workshops guide members through 4 stages of Product Management: Research, Planning, Prototyping, and Pitching. Over the course of a semester, members learn all the foundational skills needed to become a successful PM. You'll learn about:• Conducting insightful user interviews• Writing concise Product Requirement Documents• Utilizing Jira and Figma to their full potentialJoin PMReadyIf you're interested in attending our meetings, sign up for our Email Newsletter, join the Slack, and follow our Instagram. If you have any additional questions or comments, feel free to reach out to us by email (pmready@bu.edu).

The BU Pre-Dental Society serves Boston University students who wish to pursue a career in dentistry. We are committed to helping our members gain admission into dental school and to expose them to the profession. We provide students with shadowing, volunteering, and application preparation resources. Our panels with dental students, dental school administrators, and dentists give insight into dental school and the field of dentistry. Our society is also a great way to meet fellow students with similar interests and to share information and experiences. If you are a pre-dental student or are considering a career in dentistry, feel free to join our organization, email us to join our email list, and attend our meetings. Please visit our Instagram and Discord pages for more information! Email: predent@bu.edu

The Boston University Pre-Law Review is a student-run law journal, open to all Boston University undergraduates. Founded in 1991, the Pre-Law Review has continued to foster awareness and provide commentary on major issues facing the law and the legal profession through its publication. The PLR is published once per semester and features a wide range of topics, as our authors are given the freedom to write about anything as long as it pertains to the law. All of our contributors and staff are undergraduates, many of whom will be applying to law school. However, the PLR staff spans a variety of majors, schools, and class years, as no specific academic or experiential requirements are necessary to work on the PLR. All that is expected of members is an interest in learning more about the law and a commitment to furthering the publication

The BU Pre-Law Society offers a myriad of events for undergraduates who are planning to apply to law school or may be interested in a legal career. Some of our events include hosting visiting law schools, LSAT practice exams and strategy sessions, panels featuring current law students and practicing attorneys, and social events where students can chat informally with law school admissions officers. The PLS works closely with the Pre-Professional Advising Office at Boston University and the Boston University School of Law in order to provide resources to all BU Pre-Law students.

The Boston University Pre-Physician Assistant Club is a unique undergraduate student group that focuses on providing students with opportunities to gain knowledge and experiences in the medical field through community service and by shadowing PAs. Our mission is to inform students of the history and the purpose of the profession, provide information about the admission requirements for PA schools and on the PA application process.

Our main goal is to prepare members for veterinary school and provide outlets for volunteering. We aid members in course selection to ensure that they meet all of the undergraduate prerequisites, and we provide information about animal-related volunteer opportunities. However, you do not need to be pre-vet to join PALS. We also help students who are undecided by providing exposure to a wide variety of animals and by meeting with veterinarians who specialize in different fields. By doing so, we hope to present a realistic picture of the profession to members and to provide them with enough information to make their decision. For all non pre-veterinary members, we provide exciting trips, rewarding volunteering experiences and tons of social events. Join the only animal-related group on Boston University's campus!

The goal of the Boston University Pre-Medical Society is to support aspiring physicians throughout their undergraduate careers by providing resources and opportunities. We strive to create an inclusive environment where pre-med students feel comfortable asking questions and gaining support from their peers through mentorship. We organize hands-on events, mentorship programs, physician speaker events from various specialties, volunteer events, and more!

Pride in Business is a premier business club dedicated to the support and professional development of LGBTQ+ business leaders of all majors. We are dedicated to providing exclusive professional development opportunities and connecting LGBTQ+ students with the Diversity and Inclusion initiatives at top-tier companies. We also aim to provide a sense of community for queer individuals at Boston University as a whole.

Boston University Prison Outreach Initiative is dedicated to serving and advocating for incarcerated individuals, both locally and nationally. The core tenets of our organization are represented by our three main activities: volunteering, fundraising, and raising awareness. Our volunteer efforts will include organizing book drives for prison libraries with Prison Book Project, virtually tutoring incarcerated folks, creating Holiday Gift Bags with Concord Prison Outreach, phone-banking to politicians and clemency boards to encourage commutation of death sentences, and becoming pen pals with incarcerated people. Our fundraising activities will raise money for those who have recently been released from prison, reputable halfway houses, and legal funds for wrongfully incarcerated folks. Our educational efforts will include documentary screenings and a book club about the prison industrial complex, procuring speakers such as Sister Helen Prejean or Bryan Stevenson to speak with us about prison reform, and raising awareness via social media about the US criminal justice system.

Project Sunshine is a nonprofit organization that provides free educational, recreational, and social programs to children facing medical challenges as well as their families. We contribute to their cause in helping pediatric patients and their families through many of the activities and service trips we take in Boston. Such activities include creating Sunshine Activity kits for patients in the hospital and making winter holiday cards. We also take service trips to Boston Medical Center to work with outpatient children and Boston House to make dinner for the families staying while their children are treated at local Boston hospitals.

column1: Public Relations Student Society of America
column4: The Public Relations Student Society of America (PRSSA) is the foremost organization for students interested in public relations and communications. We seek to advance the public relations profession by nurturing generations of future professionals. We advocate rigorous academic standards for public relations education, the highest ethical principles, and diversity in the profession. PRSSA is made up of more than 10,000 students and advisers organized into 300 plus Chapters in the United States and one in Argentina. We are headquartered in New York City and led by a National Committee of PRSSA and PRSA members. We have a rich history of support from our parent organization, the Public Relations Society of America (PRSA), which offers professional development, networking opportunities, and news. PRSSA helps you enhance your education, broaden your network and launch your career in public relations.

The Puerto Rican Student Association welcomes every Boston University student interested in getting involved with the Puerto Rican culture. Our mission is to foster a sense of community among students at BU who grew up with Puerto Rican heritage, whether they are first, second, or third generation. Through events within the Boston University community and the greater Boston area, our members will strengthen and foster new ties with the Puerto Rican culture and traditions. This association will serve as a hub for members to find common ground with other students with similar experiences and/or upbringing. Through meetings and organized social events, members will learn what it means to be Puerto Rican on the island, in the United States, and in Boston University. This club strives to create a fun and welcoming environment by bringing a little piece of that Puerto Rican flavor to BU's campus and the greater Boston area.

The Queer Activist Collective ("Q") is Boston University's largest LGBTQ+ student organization dedicated to ensuring the awareness, visibility, & full inclusion of the LGBTQ+ community. We are committed to creating programming that is uplifting and affirming for all LGBTQ+ community members. As a majority QTBIPOC & TGNCI Executive Board, we are especially passionate about supporting & advocating for communities who are often excluded from mainstream LGBTQ+ spaces. We host programming that includes events such as mental & sexual health workshops, BU faculty & staff panels, Know Your Rights legal workshops, game nights, allyship workshops, drag shows, & much more. For questions, more info on how to get involved, help connecting with resources, or ideas on how we can better support you and the LGBTQ+ community at BU, please email us at queer@bu.edu! Check out our comprehensive BU/Boston LGBTQ+ resource guides here!

The LOCK Honorary Service Society is the oldest student organization at Questrom, established in 1924 by Professor Charles Stratton and Lyman Phillips. Many of the most prominent Questrom affiliates, including former Dean of Questrom Louis E. Lataif and the former Dean Ken Freeman, are LOCK members. LOCK was founded and still operates on the belief that those who have the privilege of scholarship must share what they have gained. LOCK members aim to fulfill that responsibility by providing their peers in Boston University with tutoring help in all required Questrom courses, tutoring nights in the dorms, study halls during finals period, and student success panels at local high schools. LOCK also aspires to foster a sense of community service through volunteering events in the greater Boston community.

As members of the Boston University Questrom School of Business Undergraduate Student Government, our primary responsibility is to the Undergraduate Students in the Questrom School of Business to ensure that we are creating an inclusive environment that enhances the Questrom undergraduate community and student life. This includes 1. Enhancing students' academic, career, and social experiences, 2. Advocating on behalf of the undergraduate population, and 3. Facilitating communication between Questrom students, faculty, administration, alumni, and the greater Boston University community.

The American Red Cross is a national, nonprofit organization aimed at the betterment of American life. It participates in disaster services, blood services, citizenship classes, health and safety training, and an assortment of other areas. The American Red Cross aims at educating the public to prevent and assist in disasters. Its volunteers work around the clock to make this mission a success. It does this through services that are consistent with its congressional charter and the principles of the International Red Cross Movement. In addition, BU Red Cross Volunteers will develop and offer services that address critical human, health, and safety needs of not only the BU community, but of the entire greater Boston area!

A Chinese student-based theater club in Boston, our mission is to create, direct, and perform captivating dramas while fostering cultural exchange. Through our productions, we aim to showcase the rich tapestry of Chinese culture and bridge connections with diverse communities.

column1: Reformed University Fellowship at Boston University
column4: RUF is a Christian community at BU open to students from all backgrounds. We believe in genuine friendships, sincere pursuit of spiritual growth, and positive engagement with the campus and world. Join us at one of our regular events!

Rhythm N Beat Step Team is a team that promotes the beauty of Black culture through step dancing. As a group, we work to build a community within a community by connecting people across campus through this art. Aside from member responsibilities such as attending practice and practicing steps in their freetime, members will also have a fun and safe space to escape from academic, social, and even the internal stressors that they may deal with. RnB is open to anyone who is interested in joining! We serve a performance group, but we hold workshops and spread education about Black culture as well! Check us out on instagram @rnbstep!

The Retail, Luxury & Consumer Association (RLC) brings together students passionate about the luxury industry through speaker events, brand-partnered consulting programs, retail experiences, and an alumni mentorship program. RLC provides members with direct exposure and opportunities to learn, connect, and grow across fashion, beauty, hospitality, and beyond. Fill out the Membership Form to receive updates on applications and upcoming events. (Note: Requesting membership on Terrier Central does not automatically add you to the mailing list.)

BURPG was founded in 2003 as the BU Rocket Team. We are a primarily undergraduate student organization devoted to the testing and development of liquid rockets and rocket engines. We are open to all students who share a love of aerospace and learning. By giving our members hands-on experience and team-based projects, we create some of the most capable engineers, computer scientists, and designers. Our current goal is to launch the largest liquid rocket ever launched by a university.NOTE: WE DO NOT USE ENGAGE TO CONNECT WITH NEW MEMBERS. TO JOIN, VISIT http://burpg.org/new-members AND FILL OUT THE FORM

The Boston University Rotaract Club is an international, young-professional, service organization for adults, ages 18 to 30. Rotaract is the college chapter of Rotary International, an organization centered around community service. Our club is within District 7910 and works closely with the Brookline Rotary Club for volunteering events and networking opportunities. Our club has a focus on community service with the community of Boston, while also incorporating events to encourage social bonding and professional development. Our club is implementing "Sessions of Service", where every 2 months (half a school semester) we will have a different community service focus (education, environment, homelessness, etc.), and we will plan most of our events to fit with the theme. This session (Oct, Nov, Dec) our focus is on food. Current/planned events include: Thrive Well cooking program, Meal Train cooking program, Project Linus Blanket Making (w/ Brookline Rotary), Cookie Chats: Networking with Brookline Rotary, and more. We are always open to new members, ideas, and opportunities!

BU's Club XC & Track Team welcomes student-athletes of all skill levels to train, compete, set goals, make friends, and improve PRs. Let's run! Team membership is open to all BU students of all ability levels. We offer workouts and meets for those interested competitive distance running, laid back runs for those interested in recreational running, and sprinting for those interested in speedwork and general fitness.

Welcome to the Russian Speaking Society! We are a student-run organization, which aims to bring together people of Russian speaking backgrounds with those interested in Russian language and culture, and the rest of the BU community. We organize interactive events to bring people together interested in the Russian/Soviet culture. (Delicious Russian food is always present.)

Sabor Latino's mission is to ignite a passion for Latinx culture through the mesmerizing fusion of music and dance. Completely student-run and representing a vibrant facet of the Latinx community at Boston University, they are committed to spreading awareness and celebrating diversity. From the infectious rhythms of bachata, salsa, merengue, and reggaeton to a world of diverse Latin dances, Sabor Latino aims to captivate hearts, spotlight Boston's vibrant community, and forge lasting connections through our dynamic performances.

Our club, Sports Analytics Group, aims to bring together students who are passionate about sports and teach them about analytics and the world of sports statistics. We plan to do this through bi-weekly meetings and various professional and recreational events, like speaker panels, networking events, sports viewing parties, bracket-making, and field visits. Further, we are providing a structured curriculum for those members interested in learning more technical skills involved in sports analytics. We aim to build this curriculum to introduce concepts such as statistics and basic programming to assist those who may be unfamiliar with concepts outside of their pursued majors. The culmination of this curriculum is to allow club members to create a research project, with the ability to collaborate with others and leverage their knowledge into presentable and thought-provoking insights. This will allow club members to build a professional portfolio. Overall, we want this club to be a space for those who enjoy sports and statistics to come together and collaborate both on projects and research, but also in casual conversation and on fun events to meet new people and connect!

Sargent Student Government is an organization for any and all Sargent College undergraduates. Each class within Sargent has a board of officers. Over the course of the year, SAR student government is responsible for organizing events- both recreational and academic. In the past, SAR Student Government has strengthened the bonds between classmates and faculty by organizing events such as Coffee and Conversation with the Dean, Sargent Celtics Night, Sargent Night at the Sox, Formal and guest speakers. Students who participate meet and gain knowledge and advice from each other as well as working with other colleges and faculty. Our mission is to create and strengthen relationships by providing fun and educational events for everyone in Sargent College.

Invitation to Juniors and Seniors in Sargent College who have achieved a GPA in the top 10% of their class. Induction is in the Fall each year. We focus on professional development and serve as a valuable connection to Sargent College alumni.

The Saudi Cultural Club brings together Saudi and non-Saudi students who share a deep interest in Saudi Arabia's rich culture and history. Our mission is to build a vibrant, inclusive community through engaging events, traditional and modern cultural celebrations, and career-focused initiatives. We strive to foster a strong sense of belonging, mutual understanding, and meaningful connection among our members. By celebrating heritage, promoting dialogue, and encouraging collaboration, we aim to keep the community connected and create a lasting impact on campus.

column1: SciBU: Journal of Undergraduate Science and Research
column4: Section 1. Purpose SciBU is a life sciences journal at Boston University. Managed by undergraduates with guidance from a Student Group Advisor, this organization creates a forum for undergraduate students to discuss and exchange their perspectives on the life sciences and its role in society. SciBU regularly publishes articles on its website and produces an annual print edition available for in-person distribution. Undergraduate students are encouraged to submit original works of life sciences writing, news, research, and art for publication. Section 2. Current Objectives To provide the undergraduate students of Boston University with numerous opportunities to explore scientific editing and writing through events, seminars, and submissions. To provide Editorial Board members of SciBU with various opportunities for involvement in aspects of scientific publishing, writing, editing, funding, design, etc. To collaborate with BU academic departments, student organizations, UROP participants, and writing and biology classes to solicit submissions. To develop experienced science communicators and promote the value of effective science communication in academia, industry, journalism, etc.

SEAA is an organization providing the space for students to promote East African cultures and socio-political issues related to East Africa and the diaspora. East African countries (and their related ethnic groups and cultures) represented include: Burundi, Comoros, Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Rwanda, Seychelles, Somalia, Somaliland, Sudan, South Sudan Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.

column1: School of Hospitality Administration Student Government
column4: The School of Hospitality Administration Student Government (SHAgov) is a forum for the academic and social interests of the students of SHA. SHAgov coordinates programs and events within the school and represents SHA as part of the larger Boston University student community. SHAgov is also the umbrella organization for the various trade associations and student groups organized within the school. Any student pursuing studies in the School of Hospitality Administration is automatically eligible for membership in SHAgov, and we encourage active participation from the student body as we pursue our shared initiatives for our school and its communities.

SHADES is a community-centered organization for Boston University's queer and trans students of color. SHADES is the home for BU's QTBIPOC students on campus. We provide a safe space for these students to find community, express themselves and engage with events that center and cater to our experiences. We host meetings where our members can both engage in enriching conversations about topics and issues related to our experiences and enjoy unique, dynamic social events to relax and have fun. Additionally, we love to collaborate with other student groups, organizations and businesses that align with our vision and mission!

Since its creation in 2003 by a group of Shakespeare enthusiasts, the Boston University Shakespeare Society has worked tirelessly to bring the good word of the Bard to the community. The Society is certainly not your average theater group. We have put on shows, hosted trips to local plays and Renaissance festivals, and brought Shakespeare's words to the wider world. We are always looking for new members--auditions are held at the beginning of every semester and we have other events for those who don't wish to perform. While approaching the BU theater community can sometimes be a daunting and difficult task, the Society prides itself on its great community of members. We make up nearly every school and class at BU, both undergrads and grad students, creating a diverse and extremely fun-loving group of people.
A community of driven young women joined together in sisterhood.

Welcome to Boston University's chapter of Sigma Kappa! We strive to empower women and our community through various philanthropic and sisterhood-building events. As the oldest existing chapter of Sigma Kappa, the Delta Chapter is dedicated to the values established by our founders – friendship, service and loyalty, and personal growth. As members of the Greek community at BU, we are also dedicated to putting forth concerted efforts on expanding diversity, equity, and inclusion within our chapter. We're always happy to answer any questions, and invite you to browse our Instagram (@sigmakappabu) for our chapter's latest information! If you are interested in recruitment or have questions about what it's like to be a Sigma Kappa, please do not hesitate to email us (sigkapprez@gmail.com) for more information!
Sigma Chi at Boston University is the Iota Upsilon Chapter of the Sigma Chi International Fraternity governed by the values of Friendship, Justice, and Learning.

SABU's mission is to encourage an on-campus community that spreads awareness of the Sikh religion and inspires others to engage in community service. By bringing together Sikhs at Boston University, we can participate in events together, attend Gurudwara services near Boston, and discuss the prevalence of our beliefs and values in helping us cope with today's issues.

We are a cultural organization dedicated to promoting Singaporean culture in BU. We aim to connect people from all walks of life through our food and events! Also, we hope to make SSA a home away from home for people who identify with Singapore.

Sisters United strives to empower young Black and Brown women at Boston University through the provision of mentorship opportunities, on-campus engagements, and off-campus excursions. Be sure to follow us on instagram @sistersunitedbu and subscribe to our newsletter to stay updated with all our events and general body meetings!

Slippery When Wet, lovingly referred to as 'Slipps', is Boston University's best example of teamwork. The group is made up of a rotating cast of Boston University undergraduates that write and perform original sketch comedy shows each semester. Slipps have written and performed dozens of sold-out shows on BU's campus, including such favorites as , "A Rift In Time: Here Comes Rashmi!", "How to Kiss" and this semester's knockout hit, "Scared of Science", an exploration through the fear of the known. We have hosted tens upon tens of events, including comedy shows, dance marathons, and a cappella festivals. We've also performed at sketch comedy festivals around the country, including: University of Pennsylvania Comfest Skidmore National College Comedy Festival Chicago Sketch Comedy Festival Brandeis Sketch Comedy Festival Sketchfest NYC Best of the Best Sketchfest (Portland, OR) Tufts Laughs of Love Comedy Festival We have also been recognized by professional sketch comedy groups, including Pangea 3000, Two Fun Men, Harvard Sailing Team, and The Whitest Kids U Know. Also, some of us are single.

We're a fun and easy-going club with multiple games in the Smash Bros. series for all its members to play! We want BU students to get to know fellow gamers and Smashers on campus. The Smash Society hosts tournaments along with other events. IF YOU WANT TO JOIN PLEASE JOIN OUR DISCORD HERE

column1: Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers
column4: The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) was founded in November 2007 to help Asian heritage scientific and engineering professionals achieve their full potential. Organizations existed for other affinity groups - The National Society of Black Engineers, the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers, and the Society of Women Engineers - and there was a need for a similar organization where students representing all of the pan Asian cultures could connect and support each other. SASE is dedicated to the advancement of Asian heritage scientists and engineers in education and employment so that they can achieve their full career potential. In addition to professional development, SASE also encourages members to contribute to the enhancement of the communities in which they live. SASE's mission is to Prepare Asian heritage scientists and engineers for success in the global business world. Celebrate diversity on campuses and in the workplace. Provide opportunities for members to make contributions to their local communities. If you're interested in getting involved, sign up for our newsletter and follow our instagram for updates on events! If you have any additional questions or comments, feel free to reach out to us by email.

The Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE-BostonU) is an organization dedicated to the empowerment of the Hispanic community in Boston and Boston University through STEM access, awareness, support, and development. We reach our goals by providing our members the support they need to succeed, both academically and professionally through various workshops and Study Nights geared towards bridging the gaps in those fields! Not only is SHPE-BostonU a professional organization, but we also encourage and foster the feeling of a familia of Latinx students in STEM at Boston University. We have social events to get to know one another in a more relaxed atmosphere such as mixers with other SHPE chapters or going to try Hispanic food around Boston. And we also host events that celebrate the beauty of the Latinx culture and community such as Cafecitos which are culturally geared discussions on topics such as mental health or colorism! SHPE-BostonU welcomes everyone from any background, race, ethnicity or major to join our organization! As long as you also want to empower the Hispanic community in STEM, you are eligible and more than welcome to join! Welcome to your familia!

The Boston University Society of Professional Journalists is a student chapter of the national organization, comprised of students within the BU journalism community. BU SPJ hosts educational events, provides a network between students and professionals in the field, and promotes the SPJ goal of improving and protecting journalism.

The BU chapter of Society of Women Engineers (SWE) is a collegiate section in National SWE. We're part of region F, which is also known as the New England Region. At BU SWE, our mission is to serve and empower women in STEM, promote the engineering profession as a positive force in improving the quality of life, and demonstrate the value of diversity. Our community is open to any and all students who wish to empower women in STEM. Click the link to our website below to learn more!

We are an interdenominational ministry committed to spreading the Gospel of Jesus Christ. Our mission is to help fulfill the Great Commission in our generation (Matt. 28:18-20) by winning, building, and sending in the power of the Holy Spirit. We hope to build the body of Christ through prayer, evangelism, and discipleship. It is our desire that we would be used by God to help reach students and faculty with the Gospel so that every person on campus will know someone who truly follows Jesus Christ. Isaiah 53:2 “He grew before him like a tender shoot, and like a root out of dry ground. He had no beauty or majesty to attract us to him, nothing in his appearance that we should desire him.” SOON is a Korean synonym for tender shoot (sprout).

Here at the Study of Religions Club we provide a casual space to discuss all things religion: traditions, beliefs, rituals, politics, and even things that you might not think involve religion! As students in the Religion Department, we want to help make studying religion fun and engaging for everyone! You do not have to be a religion major/minor to join. For the upcoming academic year, we have a number of ideas for events. These events include game nights, movie screenings, faculty presentations, and conferences! Please contact us if you have any ideas of events you would like to see!

SOSH will serve to foster a community for students who are enthusiastic about science fiction and horror motifs including but not limited to conspiracies, magic, and the supernatural. Our goals include hosting weekly laid-back meetings, screenings and discussions and working to network and collaborate with other student organizations in the BU community. SOSH welcomes anyone intrigued about horror and sci-fi in books, movies, or any other art forms — “connoisseurs” and newcomers to the genres alike.

SoulAAn, the Generational Black American Student Organization(GBA) at Boston University, is committed to advancing the cultural enrichment, academic excellence, and social empowerment of GBA students on campus. We aim to empower by providing resources and a supportive environment for GBA students to succeed academically and cultivate leadership skills. We celebrate our culture through hosting engaging events, workshops, and cultural celebrations that educate and enlighten the campus community about the richness of Black history and heritage. We seek to get involved both on campus and within the wider community while addressing pertinent issues impacting GBA students on campus and in admissions. In addition, we aim to work collaboratively with other student organizations in the Diaspora, faculty, and staff. In alignment with these principles, SoulAAn is dedicated to creating a space where generational Black American students can flourish, connect, and make a meaningful impact both on campus and beyond. While we are a “minority within a minority” on campus, this term doesn't define us—it is through our intellect, cultural prowess, and rich history that we form a longstanding community of generational Black Americans on campus.

South Campus Residence Hall Association is an organization built to direct and guide matters affecting student life in the South Campus residence halls in cooperation with the administration of the college and the apartment/residence hall councils. It is dedicated to planning and implementing programs to encourage community, education and development, and works to promote better communication and understanding between residence hall students and the college administration. South Campus Residence Hall Association is committed to hosting new, exciting, as well as traditional events throughout the academic year to build a sense of community among its residents.

Spoon University provides students with the chance to learn, share and talk about food via an online food publication, ultimately building a community around food. We aim to take advantage of Boston's incredible food scene and share some of our experiences through photographs, articles and social media. Our members are always sharpening their writing, photography, marketing and social media skills; all valuable experience that can be placed on their resume. BU's chapter of Spoon is one of many around the world! Spoon University has three main goals: (1) to empower students to create something meaningful and long-lasting on campus (2) to give students experience in food, journalism, online media and marketing (3) to create a strong community on campus focused on food. There is a $15 fee for each member, which is justified by the many benefits Spoon University provides. As a member, you have the chance to get exclusive access to food events and promotional giveaways and gain national recognition for your hard work and content that is published. We've worked with many different restaurants in Boston, whether it was an icing class with Magnolia or a promotional partnership with Jugos Supremo, our members are sure to experience and explore the food of Boston!

Stage Troupe is Boston University's oldest and largest extracurricular performing arts group for non-theatre majors. For over seventy years, Stage Troupe has been a leader among student-run campus organizations, providing the Boston University community with high-quality shows. Stage Troupe is managed by an executive board of six elected undergraduates and overseen by a student group advisor. Each year, we present six mainstage shows, including the Family & Friends Weekend Show and Theatre in Action in the spring. Every production is selected through popular vote by the membership. General meetings are held monthly with the entire membership. Stage Troupe also offers a variety of special projects to foster new work and creative alternatives to mainstage shows. Every year we produce a one-act festival as well as 24-hour theatre weekends in addition to many other events. Stage Troupe's special projects aim to cultivate fresh, new ideas and respond to the desires of the membership. We are committed to our motto of “learning by doing,” so prior experience is not necessary to join Stage Troupe. If you have an interest in any aspect of theatre—acting, teching, writing, directing, or producing—you can do it in Troupe! Our group continues to grow and we look forward to the countless opportunities to make Stage Troupe the leading performing arts group on campus. Check out our website and social media (linked below) to see more and find out what we're up to this summer!
BU Stand-up Club is an organization for stand-up comedy and those who love it. We aim to organize shows for campus comedians and invite professional comedians based on members' suggestions.

We believe that all students at Boston University deserve the right to learn the importance and skills of stock trading. Stock Trading can be complex and daunting, but with the right help it can become one of the best ways to make money with your idle cash. We plan on teaching students various topics within the trading realm including but not limited to Stocks, Options, Fixed Income, and Futures. Current club meetings are Thursday 7:30pm at HAR 222! At STABU, we recognize that everyone brings diverse perspectives to the table. Throughout the semester we will teach members how to create trading plans based on their personal characteristics. We also hope to go into the emotional aspect of trading, lessons that will not only be helpful for trading but for life as well. The goal of these teachings is to give students the resources they need to become successful and hopefully profitable traders whilst studying here at Boston University. We also plan on hosting various projects where members can analyze significant stock market events from a technical standpoint. At Stock Trading at Boston University we will teach you how to go from working for you money to learning how to make your money work for you! STABU is a club dedicated to teaching students at Boston University how to trade the various avenues of the stock market. In meetings, this organization will deal with topics such as: Intro to stocks Stock Intricacies and studies Introduction to Options Trading Options Intricacies Fixed Income Futures Trading Strategies

The Student Elections Commission (SEC) is the body of the Judicial Branch of BU Student Government that oversees and runs the elections for the Executive Board, At-Large Parties, student resource body, and for some college governments. The SEC is composed of three Co-Chairs and seven Commissioners. Together, we're in charge various operations from drafting election rules to advertising to event planning. SEC's mission is to ensure impartiality, fairness, and fun in all aspects of the electoral process and provide a platform for future BU leaders. The SEC requires a diverse team of enthusiastic individuals, ready to apply their unique experiences and skills. Undergraduate students who feel comfortable with logistics, budgeting, marketing, and/or crisis management are encouraged to apply. It is important to note that experience in these areas can be helpful, but it is not necessary to succeed in this role. The SEC will meet at least once every two weeks in the Fall semester. These meetings can last from one to two hours depending on the workload for each meeting. In the Spring Semester, the SEC will meet at least once per week, since all election events, including campaigning and voting periods, take place in the Spring. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to us through email (election@bu.edu). You can also check us out on our website (http://www.bu.edu/election/) or Instagram (@bostonu_sec).

The Boston University Student Government (BUSG) is your representative governing body at Boston University. USG's primary goal is listening to you and accomplishing or advocating for the changes you want to see on our campus.

BU Students for Reproductive Freedom advocates for healthy/safer sexuality, sex positivity, abortion access, comprehensive sexuality education, and push for legislation that expands access to reproductive healthcare. As a registered Planned Parenthood campus organizing group, we are responsible for representing them at BU. On campus, we host a variety of events and pass out hundreds of condoms and other sexual health education resources. Reproductive justice is not an isolated movement, and we want to raise awareness about how socioeconomic status, culture, race, gender, sexuality, immigration, environmental issues, etc., all impact autonomy and justice.

BU Students Learning about Israel-Palestine is a student group committed to academic understanding of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict through a range of weekly or biweekly activities including presentations on aspects of the conflict, discussions, and documentaries. We are open to all including all levels of knowledge related to the conflict as we too are learning and we invite all perspectives to join in for meaningful discussion.

As Boston University's only integrated Caribbean cultural organization, SOCA is dedicated to celebrating and promoting West Indian culture. Through an array of events and discussions, we aim to highlight the richness of Caribbean culture including our history, food, current events, and the arts. We also seek to educate the wider BU community of issues relating to and affecting the Caribbean region.

"Suno", or "Listen" in Hindi, is Boston University's premiere South Asian/Western Fusion A Cappella team. Established in 2001, its members have been working to create music that blends cultures. Suno's mix of south asian and western music goes beyond lyrics and notes on a page; it redefines what it means to be part of a team and more importantly, a part of a family. This team has had the privilege of performing and competing all across the country from Sahana 2018 in Los Angelos to All American Awaaz in Chicago last year. However, their recent album “Iss Baar Suno” is their new platform of expressing multiple generations of members and various eras of their music. We also host showcases featuring our team and other a cappella and dance teams from BU and from other universities. Contact us to learn more, and remember: just listen!

The Game: Survivor as a show has a simple format. Every week there is a “challenge” (see challenges section for further details), where the winner(s) of the challenge are immune and safe from being “voted out” of the game. Throughout the week, players can talk and strategize to vote off one of the players that is not immune from being voted out, culminating in the votes being read. The game can be full of twists and turns and surprise “double vote offs”, all until a winner is crowned at the end of the semester, dubbed “sole survivor”. The Challenges: Each challenge in Survivor BU typically follows one of 3 categories: mental, physical, or social. Mental challenges tend to be memory games like brain-teasers or puzzles, like a jigsaw or slide puzzle. Physical challenges tend to involve running and endurance tests. For example, we have had players run to grab puzzle pieces, toss bean bags and run to pick them up, or on the endurance side, hold up one arm for as long as possible or stand on one foot for as long as possible. Social challenges include games that test a players ability to make connections and draw conclusions about said connections. The main social challenge we have done every semester is called “Touchy Subjects” where players are asked questions about each other in the large group, for example, everyone is asked “Who is most likely to sleep through their 9AM class?” and everyone will answer a fellow player, and the people who answer the player who has the most votes will get a point. Therefore, challenges are fun, quick, and a large part of what makes the game like the CBS show, though at a much less extreme level. Our Production Team: Survivor: BU's production team is an ever growing team of students who are interested in Survivor, reality TV, and film and TV production as a whole. Our group of students range from those who have played our club's game, to those who want to help out without the pressure of signing up to be a contestant. More significantly, contestants who are voted out before the jury section of the game, (around halfway through the semester), are encouraged to join production in order to join our greater community outside of the competitive game and help our production team run smoothly. Production members of Survivor: BU gain knowledge of still/moving camerawork through smartphones and standing cameras, general footage sharing and dynamic editing, and collaborative set design and management when an episode is recorded. Many production members know that the amount that you put in for the show is how much entertainment value you will get out. This means our production members can individually choose how much to put in, but because of that choice, there's a general consensus that production has to be a strong backbone to ensure contestants have an enjoyable and fair game. Our Community & Events: Survivor: BU has many outside activities beyond the show production happening during the semester. For one, every Wednesday we meet to play board games and watch episodes of the show Survivor, so we build a community around our status as fans of the show and play board games together to bond. Additionally, many players who are voted out of the game stick around afterwards! For example, every single player from our last season either joined our production crew, attended future production shoots or attended the season finale party, so everyone is encouraged to return to club events regardless of status in the game. We also host minigames of Survivor and other similar game shows during the semester, so even when the game is not being played there are other social strategy games offered to club members. Overall, we encourage everyone to stick around during the season and actively host events like Survivor watch parties, plan board game nights and host other strategy shows for club members to participate in! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Hj_Fwv5ejk

The Sustainable Oceans Alliance is a youth-led organization that empowers students to become leaders in preserving the health and sustainability of our oceans. With education, resources and collaborative opportunities, SOA aims to inspire students to create measurable impact by incentivizing social and environmental investments and fostering cross-sector partnerships. Our vision is to provide a platform for innovative cross-sector collaboration through which business practices, effective legislation, and cutting edge technology can catalyze solutions.

The Boston University Sustainable Business Club's is dedicated to fostering a community of future business leaders committed to environmental and social responsibility. Our mission is to allow students to be involved with business opportunities that help inspire, educate, and empower students to integrate sustainability into their careers and contribute positively to the global business landscape. Through guest speakers we will inspire members of our club to become involved in the sustainable sector of business, showing jobs and functions of this path in the market. We are dedicated to raising awareness about the importance of sustainability all while engaging in meaningful discussions on environmental and social issues, which we will share through our monthly newsletter. In addition, members will be given the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with the aspects of merging business success while keeping sustainable practices through semester-long case competitions. Our vision for the Sustainable Business Club at Boston University is to be a pioneering force in reshaping the future of business through college students who are emerging into the workforce. We aspire to create a world where sustainability is ingrained in the DNA of every organization, where business serves as a catalyst for positive change, and where the next generation of leaders are unwavering champions of ethical, environmentally conscious, and socially responsible practices.

column4: The Boston University Chapter of the Society of Women in Space Exploration is dedicated to providing a safe space for women and minorities interested in space-related fields to collaborate over shared interests and experiences.
Girls Inc is an organization dedicated to empowering young girls and championing women's potentials and aspirations, to pursue broader futures through the mentorship of college-aged women.

The Boston University Taiwanese American Student Association (BUTASA) is dedicated to promoting and sharing Taiwanese culture with the school community and beyond. We welcome everyone to join our organization to learn more about Taiwan's history, culture, politics, and language through social, cultural, and educational events. We hope that these events will allow others to learn and gain a better understanding of the Taiwanese American identity. Click here to sign up for our mailing list

The main purpose of Taiwanese Overseas Students Association (TOSA) is to provide Taiwanese international students service, advice, and networking opportunities and share Taiwanese culture on BU campus. We assist students with Taiwanese background to adapt to American culture, engage with domestic American students, and enrich their college experience. We create opportunities to enhance the relationship between TOSA members and the BU community. While we present cultural events and activities to all BU students that stimulate a better understanding of Taiwanese culture, we also add cultural diversity to Boston University.

TAMID Consulting & Investment Group is a nonprofit organization that develops the professional skills of students through hands-on interactions with the Israeli economy. TAMID integrates the next generation of entrepreneurs and business professionals with Israel through a comprehensive education curriculum, pro-bono consulting for Israeli startups, capital market investment research, and a summer internship program in Israel.

Tau Beta Pi was founded in 1885 to mark, in a fitting manner, those who have conferred honor upon their alma mater by distinguished scholarship and exemplary character as undergraduates in the field of engineering, or by their attainments as alumni in the field of engineering, and to foster a spirit of liberal culture in the engineering colleges. The BU Massachusetts Eta Chapter strives to embody the principles of the Societal Engineer and uphold the honor of the Tau Beta Pi Association.

Tau Beta Sigma is a multi-gendered national sorority founded to help promote and serve college and university bands across the country. As members we strive to help the Director of Bands with any work that will help to further the program and also always attempt to demonstrate leadership, a positive attitude, and enthusiasm at any band events or activities. Our primary goal is to help every band member have the most positive musical and social experiences possible here at BU.

We are Terpsichore (terp-SIK-oh-ree), Boston University's premier a cappella group! Affectionately known as Terps, we are a tight-knit, inclusive group of treble-voiced people dedicated to sharing our love of music by creating and performing complex arrangements of a wide variety of music. Our repertoire includes songs from artists such as Lorde, Beyoncé, Rachel Chinouriri and more! Interested in auditioning? Find up-to-date information our website!

Terrier Motorsport is a student-run organization that is focused on the design and development of a fully-electric car, in preparation for the yearly Formula Hybrid & Electric competition. Our team is highly focused on pushing the boundaries of Boston University's education by offering a hands-on experience that requires teamwork, and a variety of special skills that will prepare our members for their desired after college careers. From engineering to marketing, we are a racing team that has something to offer everyone.

The test club is used by the Student Activites Office for demonstrations, trainings, and basic information to ensure all organizations are well-informed. PSA: This is stricly an example club managed by SAO staff only.

Thai Student Association at Boston University is a cultural organization that aims to promote Thai cultures in various aspects - Thai traditional dance, Thai cuisine, Thai sports, and the importance of various traditions in Thailand. We are open to the entire BU community who are interested in our organization.

The Buzz is a lifestyle magazine geared toward all Boston University students. The focus of the Buzz is on news and happenings on the BU campus and in the city of Boston—the two communities to which all Boston University students belong. We hope to inform students about what is going on around them and inspire them to explore opportunities for fun and education on and off campus. Sections include: campus, city, culture, fashion, food, music, wellness, travel, and opinion. The Buzz was founded during the Spring 2009 semester by magazine journalism students Allie Vasilakis (COM '11) and Marisa Morrison (COM '11) with the goal of establishing an on-campus magazine of which all students could be a part. Every step in creating the magazine is completed by current Boston University students. From writers to photographers to graphic designers and models, positions on the Buzz's staff are filled by members of our talented student body. The Buzz prints one issue at the end of each academic semester (Fall and Spring semesters) and debuted with its premiere issue at the end of the Fall 2009 semester. Copies of The Buzz are distributed at the GSU Link at indicated times during the semester. If you are interested in advertising with The Buzz, please send an inquiry to the.bu.buzz@gmail.com. Our magazine is printed through Century Type. For more information on Century Type, visit centurytype.com.

The Dear Abbeys has long been known as the premier all-male a cappella group of Boston University since its foundation 33 years ago. With a dynamic repertoire of in-house arrangements of songs ranging from classic rock to R&B to modern pop, the Abbeys keep it fresh and fun everywhere they go. After winning the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella (ICCA??) in 2005, the Abbeys have performed in stadiums, on street corners, and everywhere in between. Other accolades include winning the 2015 All A Cappella Live Competition and the 19th Annual Faneuil Hall A Cappella Competition. Their edgy pop arrangements can rock fashion shows, and their classy style is frequently heard at weddings, corporate events, charity functions, high schools, and the greater Boston community. Beyond Beantown, the group has enjoyed sharing their talents around the country. Through yearly tours, the Abbeys have spread music to students and audiences in New York, DC, Princeton, Philadelphia, California, New Orleans, and even Alaska. The Abbeys aim to inspire, inform and entertain??ntroducing young thinkers to the arts with the hope of initiating positive change. In the past they have been so lucky as to team up with musical heavyweights like Steven Tyler, Ben Folds, NOTA, Pentatonix, and Ball in the House. To date, the Abbeys have produced twelve studio albums, with more on the way. Check out our latest album, Under A Rest, now available on all streaming platforms! Recently, the Abbeys have also focused their creative energy on short films and music videos, all of which can be found on YouTube @dearabbeys (The Dear Abbeys). The Dear Abbeys hold auditions every Fall semester in mid-September, where further information can be found on the @dearabbeys instagram.

The Politica at Boston University (PBU) is an academic global affairs club with an online podcast, publication, and roundtable discussions. We serve as a platform for students passionate about global affairs to engage in refined dialogue and publish interdisciplinary research on topics relevant to the modern political conversation, with focuses on the studies of law, economics, politics, and activism. We seek to fulfill the vacancy on campus of a space where students can respectfully discuss, collaborate, and publish comprehensive academic analyses centered around current affairs. At the heart of our ethos is the recognition that fostering an international board of members is crucial for the club's success. We are open to undergraduate students from all backgrounds and walks of life, as we believe that diversity and inclusivity are essential for the cultivation of insightful research and conversation. We seek to fulfill the vacancy on campus of a space where students can respectfully discuss, collaborate, and publish comprehensive academic analyses centered around current affairs. Researching contentious topics to further inform the student body enables club members to engage in their passion whilst advancing in the pursuits of knowledge and social awareness.

Word & Way is the undergraduate student association of Core, and a recognized student group organized through SAO. The members of Word & Way—representing every academic program at Boston University—seek to support and broaden the Core community by bringing discussions of Core topics and texts out of the classroom, for the benefit of all interested students and BU community members. Word and Way is also a place to hone the academic skills of Core students by providing opportunities to lead and participate in discussions, as well as to learn how to apply Core learning in everyday and professional life. By fostering connections among Core students and representing Core on campus, Word & Way seeks as well to strengthen the Core community itself.

The Beacon is a social literary journal which thrives on the imagination of Boston University's finest writers. Each outside-the-box issue uplifts student voices, offering writers a platform to share ideas and an inclusive space for creative works. Beyond our pages, the Beacon is the writer's hub of campus. Through events such as writer's workshops and open mic nights, the Beacon gathers literary-like minds together to discover, discuss, and celebrate creative writing. ???s Boston University's Premiere Student Publication, the original 1876 Beacon is as old as The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, and born in the same year as Jack London. Before the Beacon disbanded in 1951, its publications witnessed and marked both World Wars, the end of gendered segregation in higher education and, of course, the many infrastructural changes that have occurred at BU since its creation. In 2019, BU Student Jonathan Han decided it was time to bring the Beacon back, hoping to offer students a vital platform to share their writing with the Boston community. The Rebranded 2022 Beacon as you see it now is constantly evolving, but continues to fulfill the wishes of Jonathan and the long, long line of Beacon writers, providing a safe space to uplift student voices. The Beacon strives to celebrate the creative writers of Boston University. Our team rallies around the goals of building a flourishing writing community here at BU, and offering a safe space for students to feel supported in their writing endeavors. We do not seek perfection, and aim to actively break down the stereotypes of what writing should be. We hope to encourage students to raise their voices by helping writers hone their skills, increasing access to peer-review resources, and providing opportunities for writers to make social connections. The Beacon team has big dreams for the fall 2024 semester. We are re-envisioning the Beacon as more than just a magazine, hoping to bring writers across campus together for a series of exciting social events. Our vision for the semester includes hosting: Open Mic Nights Writer's Workshops (Speed dating with our Editors!) Guest Speaker Lectures/Masterclasses Slam Poetry Competitions 2025 Issue Release Party And more! In addition to holding events, we are working towards a physical magazine publication.
