column4: The Kappa Pi chapter was chartered in May of 2022, Since then the brothers of the Kappa Pi chapter have upheld the ideals and goals of the fraternity to become good citizens and leaders in the community. Theta Chi is the fraternity of balanced men who exemplify scholarship, service, leadership, and above all else, brotherhood. Founded on the principle of friendship through the mutual assistance of every member, Theta Chi aims to provide its members with an enjoyable and fulfilling collegiate experience that also prepares them for rewarding, successful lives after graduation. Theta Chi focuses our time on developing resolute men, giving students tools to be successful in classes and in the working world. Academic achievement, involvement on campus, and forming a close brotherhood are all aspects of preparing members to reach graduation, and successfully find careers afterwards. Each semester we raise money for the USO as philanthropy and giving back to people in need is a key aspect of the organization.

Theta Tau is a professional co-ed engineering fraternity founded at the University of Minnesota in 1904. It is the oldest, largest, and foremost fraternity for engineers that has grown to over 35,000 members and 91 chapters and colonies across the nation since its inception. The purpose of Theta Tau is to instill and maintain a high standard of professionalism among its members, embrace a strong bond of fraternal fellowship, and foster the intellectual pursuits of engineering.

The Women's Network is a networking organization dedicated to redefining ambition. We are an inclusive and diverse community that emphasizes the importance of building your network, celebrating ambition, and connecting college students to each other and to leaders in a variety of industries. Many of our members have earned internships through TWN-only internships offered by companies that want to work with our high-achieving, ambitious network of students. Furthermore, our organization offers networking opportunities for members. Members who attended the annual TWN Networking Trip to NYC developed meaningful relationships with panelists at companies such as CNN, Bloomberg, CBS, NBC and Salesforce; in fact, a number of our members earned internships at companies and PR firms based in NYC. Also, speakers are able to connect our members with large networks of contacts at other firms where they can make introductions.

Trans Listening Circle (TLC) is a weekly-meeting club for people who are transgender, nonbinary, gender non-conforming, questioning, and more to find community on campus. The topics discussed at meetings include gender, self-expression, and real-world problems as they relate to members of the Boston University community. TLC aims to provide resources and (non-professional) support, both in and out of meetings, as well as spread awareness of and facilitate inclusion regarding the incredible diversity on campus. Join us on Mondays at 6:15 PM EST!

The BU Treblemakers were formed in 1996 around three fundamental ideals: fun, love, and music. Since then, generations of Trebs have rallied around these values to become one of Boston University's most irresistible all-gender a cappella groups. Over the years, many generations of Trebs have participated in producing nine studio albums and three EPs, most recently: “Afterglow,” which is streaming on all platforms. Today, the group is known for its diverse repertoire, energetic performances, and talented soloists, recently earning the title of “Best Mixed Voices Collegiate Lead Vocal” in the 2025 CARA Awards. Follow us on Instagram @butreblemakers to stay updated on our performances and latest content!

To showcase the unique and vast career field that exists within the amusement and theme park industry to other engineers, provide networking opportunities to students, explore and practice with tools and techniques used in the industry, and create a community for theme park enthusiasts.

column1: The Boston Chapter of The Urban Garden Initiative
column4: The Urban Garden Initiative (TUGI) is an international 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that uses local urban gardening to engage youth in environmental education. The organization runs through individual city-wide chapters, often started by universities, each of which create curriculum and gardens to host workshops, continuous programs, and other events for local schools and community groups. In the TUGI: Boston chapter, we prioritize engaging with our community outside of Boston University and practicing local forms of activism through education. Through this chapter, members gain experience with K-8 education centered around environmental science, both through writing and executing lesson plans. Members also gain experience in creating and maintaining urban gardens, while forming connections with the involved communities. Thus far, we have formed relationships with 3 local Boston Public Schools where we will be running 6-8 week long programs for their students, and are in the process of forming more. At one of these schools, we will be creating a new on-going community garden where this and other programs can take place. Members can take part in writing and carrying out these programs, planning and creating the garden, fundraising, art initiatives, or any other aspect of the process. We will meet bi-weekly and have sign-up sheets for members to volunteer at various events and programs throughout each month.

Boston University Turkish Student Association revamped itself to provide services to BU students. Our goal is to bring students together, enjoy Turkish culture, and build long lasting friendships that will transcend borders.

The Boston University Undergraduate Economics Association (UEA) is the leading economics student organization sponsored by the Economics Department at BU. Our mission is to build a vibrant economics community on campus by offering academic, social, and professional support to all undergraduates interested in economics. We achieve this through hosting discussions with faculty and industry experts, social events, alumni panels, professional development workshops, and more.

The UELA is an organization that prioritizes offering BU undergraduate students opportunities to expand learning and develop close relationships with others with a similar passion for literature. Our goal is to provide BU students ways to enjoy literature and apply it to their personal and professional lives. To achieve our goal, we plan to host events that encourage interaction with alumni, career professionals, and graduate students that share an interest in literature. In addition to networking with professionals, we want to host casual events so students can develop closer bonds with peers.

The purpose of UMOJA is to foster a healthy and supportive environment for Black students and all individuals interested in Black culture. We are committed to uniting students, staff, and alumni through meaningful educational, social, and community outreach programming. UMOJA also strives to provide honest, transparent, and responsive leadership that is adaptive to the evolving needs of our general body. In the coming year, we aim to strengthen our presence as both a resource and a safe space for the student community.

This group serves to connect everyone who loves the culture of ancient Greece and Rome! We discuss mythology, history, and all subjects in the field of Classics. We meet Thursdays 5:00 pm - 6:30 pm STH409 No need to stay the whole time, feel free to pop in and out! Free snacks & tea provided!Instagram: uca_bu

The Undergraduate History Association serves to promote the academic study of history as well as a resource for students who are interested in history. Our goal is to allow those with a like-minded interest in history to discover others with similar passions so that they can learn from each other, discuss various topics, and play fun games with each other. If you have any interest in history, come by and say hello! There are no requirements to join, as long as you like history!

Boston University's Undergraduate Philosophy Association holds weekly informal discussions on a variety of philosophical issues. Meetings cover topics such as artificial intelligence, epistemology, and music. All discussion topics are voted on by general members and all meetings are moderated by the E-Board. Additionally, we host a yearly lecturer, a cross-college philosophy mixer, group outings, symposiums on underrepresented philosophies, and more. The UPA is open to undergraduates from any academic background looking to join us in our love for philosophy. For more information please contact our president, Josephine Perl, at jsperl@bu.edu.

The Undergraduate Public Health Association (UPHA) at Boston University is a student group that: - Provides a community for undergraduates interested in public health from varying backgrounds (Biomedical sciences, International Relations, Anthropology, Pre-med, etc.) to discuss public health issues of interest - Helps undergraduates navigate the wealth of public health-related academic options at BU, from the Geneva internship program at the World Health Organization to the 5-year BS/MPH program. - Hosts public health lectures and discussions, and links students with the numerous public health events in and around Boston - Acts as a liason for students interested in public health to gain hands-on experience with other student groups such as Peer Health Exchange and Project HEALTH and non-profits in Boston

As a member of BUWA, you'll be a part of the diverse community that is World Literatures & Languages. We aim to bridge the gap between students spread out across the department, as well as facilitating communication between undergraduates and faculty. Becoming a resource for students looking to further their academic and/or career-oriented goals is also one of our priorities. We like to think of our group as a meeting point for all students passionate about good books, foreign languages, and discovering a global community.

We hold meetings monthly and spread awareness of key global health issues. We also have guest speakers come to our meetings to enrich our general members and give them insight into diplomatic and IR related careers. We have had Professor Mark C. Storella share his experiences of being the Ambassador to Zambia. We also hold monthly fundraisers to raise money for UNICEF's initiatives and organizations that support children. Our most successful fundraiser was the "Be Golden Fundraiser". We raised upwards of $5,500 dollars for Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in New York City that went towards progressing Pediatric Cancer Research. Our Executive Board is devoted to UNICEF's mission. Every action is for every child. We hope you will join us in our efforts to create a better world for children. Thank you for your consideration and we hope you have a great day!

Boston University's Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Team is an engineering student group focused on the emerging future of drones. We are continually advancing our active projects such as obstacle avoidance, creating more efficient drones, and improving the way in which we control our vehicles. Furthermore, with the help of our members and alumni, BU UAV wishes to expand its team and fleet to include a wider variety of students and vehicles.

Founded in the Spring of 2005, Unofficial Project (UPro) is a competitive collegiate dance team at Boston University. Since its debut, UPro has strived to develop diverse experiences for the Boston dance community by promoting the collaboration between different dance backgrounds. UPro aims to bring performances that remain true to their own artistic integrity and showcase the creativity and inspirations of individuals on the team. UPro has performed at various events on campus at Boston University as well as at other colleges around the New England area, including Northeastern University, Wellesley College, Boston College, and MIT. They have participated in various competitions including Elements and Ring The Alarm. In the fall semester, UPro hosts OVRDRV JAM, an annual two-day dance event that includes a showcase with around 15 performing teams, a freestyle competition, and over 500 audience members the first day as well as a series of workshops taught by our headliners the second day. Our last showcase, OVRDRV 14.0, was headlined by Anthony Lee.

Untangle is a multimedia artist collective founded in the aftermath of the 2021 Atlanta Spa Shootings. Through our art, we seek to untangle our identities and lived experiences, build community, and spark conversation around Asian American sociopolitical experiences. Throughout the academic year, we collaboratively work on the creation of a print zine and host community events. Based on a collectively envisioned theme, Untangle members and the BU community are welcome to submit responses and creative work for the zine. Examples of submissions have included interviews, photography, embroidery, short stories, public art, and more. Untangle members will then compile submissions and design the zine to be printed and released in time for the end-of-year launch. To further build community, we also host events related to the magazine's theme where everyone, no matter their artistic ability or background, is encouraged to reflect, engage in dialogue, and create together. Our mission is to create a welcoming and creative space where people can challenge themselves as artists and citizens within our complex sociopolitical fabric.

Upsilon Pi Epsilon (UPE) at BU is an honor society dedicated to promoting excellence in technical and computing disciplines. UPE at BU will help prepare members for the industry through professional development, meaningful and interesting projects, and a supportive professional network.

column1: Undergraduate Women in Science and Engineering
column4: Undergraduate Women in Science and Engineering (uWISE) at Boston University strives to connect and support women & non-binary individuals in STEM through workshops, mentoring relationships, social events, and community outreach. uWISE is open to all undergraduate students that support women in STEM fields and can be contacted via our Email: uwise@bu.edu, Website: https://www.buuwise.com/, or Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/uwisebu/. ** Please email us to be added to the email list and follow us on Instagram to stay up to date with our events!

Verge is a performing and training dance company, concentrating in Chinese dance and ballet training. Our repertoire spans classical, ethnic, and contemporary Chinese dance. We meet once a week, no auditions required. Just come and dance! Our rehearsals typically include a warmup session with ballet training and a Chinese dance combo. We perform in the Boston area throughout the year and hold an annual showcase in April. For more information, please visit our Instagram (@buvergedance), Facebook (/VergeDanceCompany), and Youtube channel. For performance inquiries, please contact vergedancecompany@gmail.com

Veteran Assist (VA) is a student-run organization that aims to engage students in volunteer opportunities dedicated to helping veterans, with a focus on disabled and underserved veterans, in and around the Greater Boston community. We hope to create meaningful relationships with veterans by assisting them with fundamental needs, both physically and mentally, listening to their meaningful stories, enriching them with engaging activities, and providing them with educational knowledge and resources. Our goal is to educate students about the importance of aiding our veterans, teaching them how to help with the challenges they face after returning from service.

Vibes, founded in 2000, originated as an all-female hip-hop dance crew at Boston University. Comprising vibrant performers from diverse dance backgrounds, Vibes is dedicated to expanding the art of dance and hip-hop culture within the Boston community through their original choreography and captivating stage presence. While the team takes pride in its roots of female empowerment, Vibes continually seeks to redefine and explore femininity through gender-inclusivity.

Boston University's Vietnamese Student Association (BUVSA) is a student organization that provides an opportunity for exploring, sharing, and preserving Vietnamese history, culture, and experiences. It also promotes friendship and awareness both among club members and within the Boston University campus. The Association works to advocate unity among the Vietnamese community as well as connecting ourselves with other communities as a whole. We aim to reflect this goal through cultural, educational, and social events.

Welcome to Volunteers for Inclusion and Accessibility! We are a group of Boston University student volunteers who actively support individuals with various disabilities such as autism, Asperger's, blindness, and learning disabilities. Our club reaches out to the Boston community by traveling to local schools and libraries to offer our help and support. We participate in activities such as arts and crafts, sports, board games, holiday parties, fundraisers, awareness walks, and much more! We aim to promote disability acceptance and inclusion in all that we do. If you're interested in working with individuals with disabilities, making new friends, and positively impacting your community, we invite you to join our organization! You can also stay updated on our latest news and events by following our Instagram @bostonu_via

Boston University's Vakhri Taur Diyan is an all female competitive Bhangra team dedicated to nurturing female artists in a male dominated Bhangra circuit. We focus on cultivating a team that builds and supports its dancers as well as educating the BU community on Punjabi and Sikh culture. Follow our Instagram for information on Summer 2023 tryouts!!

Wandering Minds is a student-run theater organization which seeks to provide the opportunity for students to participate in any aspect of stage production regardless of previous experience. It is open to all undergraduate Boston University students who are dedicated to entertaining the BU community and are willing to share their talents.

Section 1. Build a sense of community and hall identity and a residence that enhances the quality of life and addresses all students concerns. Section 2. Act as a liaison between hall staff and residents and to provide a channel for the expression of student ideas. Section 3. Organize, facilitate and execute programs that build community in the hall and residence. Section 4. Provide transparency between the residents and the WTRHA.

The West Campus RHA serves to provide the residence of West Campus with various events and activities which serve to foster bonds between residents and make life in West Campus more enjoyable. Our motto is: West: Where Everyone Shines Together.

Undergraduate students are represented within the Wheelock College of Education and Human Development and Boston University by an active student government. In addition to planning and providing educational, social, and professional functions, the executive board is the voice of undergraduate students in BU Wheelock. Undergraduates, through the student government, are also active participants in the Boston University Student Senate. Visit the BU Wheelock Facebook page or Instagram for more information. To contact the BU Wheelock Student Government, email: sedsg@bu.edu.

Women In Law at Boston University would strive to fill the gap that exists for young women who are interested in a pre-law path. The mission of the Women In Law Club, regardless of the historical and systemic gender inequality they may face, is to develop, nurture, and challenge students to pursue their dreams. We will develop appropriate conversations and events that will provide students with realistic and helpful pre-professional advice. We will strive to build positive interactions between mentors, mentees, peers, and advisors. Our vision is to also educate the community on legal issues through society including, but not limited to, employment, health, education, violence, access to resources and more. We will push to be an inclusive organization aiming to promote an environment of academic, professional, and legal equality. It is essential to prepare undergraduates who may be interested in a legal career and by providing a strong community of women to support each other, we can be hopeful they each achieve their dreams.
Website: https://winbostonu.wixsite.com/buwin

We are dedicated to creating a supportive community for young computer scientists of all genders and deepening awareness and interest in the many areas of CS. We feature speakers on a variety of CS topics, host career-related events, and bring together and collaborate with individuals passionate about computer science, math, engineering, business, and related fields. Computer science touches so many facets of our lives - from the virtual assistants on our smartphones to the algorithms running our medical equipment to the software that sends rockets into the stars - that it's impossible to not be “into computers.” We hope that we can help all students, regardless of gender, to see that computer science can be for everyone - dreamers, tinkerers, coders, and thinkers - and to discover all that CS has to offer.

The Latin American Business Club (LABA) is a student organization that explores the role of Latin America in global business. Open to all majors, LABA seeks to connect students with leaders, from a wide variety of industries, who have vast experience working in the Latin American region. Through speaker events, mentorship opportunities, and workshops, LABA offers a unique platform for students to gain the necessary exposure to learn about Latin America and its business ventures.

We practice meditation from the Zen Buddhist tradition. Meditation helps you develop concentration, wisdom, and peace of mind. Even if you know nothing about meditation, you are welcome to join BU Zen. Weekly meetings consist of a mind-body exercise, a relaxation practice, 15 minutes of sitting meditation, and a short talk about Buddhist philosophy and practice. Meetings conclude with tea, cookies, and time to socialize. BU Zen's advisor is Barbara Feldman, a yoga instructor at BU and the Abbot of the Cambridge Zen Center. When: Wednesdays 7:30-9pm Where: Robinson Room at Marsh Chapel. If you're not yet on our mailing list, email buzen@bu.edu. Remember to wear comfortable clothing All levels of experience are welcome. Beginner's mind preferred! Please come on time.
